text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Information for Employers  
Before You Download Your Year-End Statement  
To download your year-end statement, you will need your Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) formatted as a 15-digit number and the permanent authorization code issued by the Department of Labor (not to be confused with the PIN used to file your NJ-927 and WR-30 with the Division of Revenue). We only send this code out by mail once to each employer. You will not get a copy this year if we sent it to you in the last two years. If you can't find your code, our Division of Employer Accounts has instructions on how to retrieve it.  
- Remember, you must enter your FEIN as a 15-digit number. If your FEIN is fewer than 15 digits, add a zero (0) before the first number, and add on five zeros (00000) after the last one. For example, if your FEIN is 123456789, you must enter it as 012345678900000.
- If You Have Your Authorization Code and 15-Digit FEIN, click here to download your year-end tax statement  
Need Further Assistance?  
If you can't find your code, our Division of Employer Accounts has instructions on how to retrieve it.  
---

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Claims Related to Domestic or Sexual Violence  
Family Leave Benefits and Temporary Disability Benefits for Domestic or Sexual Violence Victims
- Family Leave benefits and Temporary Disability benefits can be claimed if you need time off from work due to domestic or sexual violence.
- Family Leave Insurance can be used to cope or seek help, while Temporary Disability Insurance is for physical or mental health issues.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Claims Related to Domestic or Sexual Violence
metadata.Header 2: Family Leave Benefits and Temporary Disability Benefits for Domestic or Sexual Violence Victims

text:
Key Points
- Family Leave Insurance provides time off for coping or seeking help.
- Temporary Disability Insurance assists in healing from illness, injury, or disability.
- Family Leave benefits can also be used for caregiving for a loved one who is a victim/survivor.
- You can claim leave either day by day or all at once.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Claims Related to Domestic or Sexual Violence
metadata.Header 2: Family Leave Benefits and Temporary Disability Benefits for Domestic or Sexual Violence Victims

text:
Program Information
- Temporary Disability benefits are for victims/survivors with an illness, injury, or disability.
- Up to 26 weeks of Temporary Disability benefits can be claimed under this program.
- Family Leave benefits are available to victims/survivors or their loved ones.
- Family Leave benefits can be used for caregiving or handling matters related to the situation.
- Up to 12 weeks or 56 individual days of Family Leave benefits can be claimed.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Claims Related to Domestic or Sexual Violence

text:
Eligibility
- Temporary Disability benefits eligibility information can be found [here](https://www.nj.gov/labor/tdi/worker/tdivictimsurvivor.shtml).
- Family Leave benefits eligibility information can be found [here](https://www.nj.gov/labor/fli/family/familyviolence.shtml).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Claims Related to Domestic or Sexual Violence

text:
Application Process
- For Family Leave benefits, complete the "FL-1 Family Leave Application."
- When applying, select "Care of family member" and specify "Coping with Domestic (or Sexual) Violence."
- Documentation may include a restraining order, prosecutor letter, or other official proof.
- Application can be faxed or mailed to the Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Claims Related to Domestic or Sexual Violence

text:
Additional Information
- Temporary Disability Insurance and Family Leave Insurance do not provide job protection.
- Information on job protection under various acts can be found [here](https://www.nj.gov/labor/workersrights/lawssigned/leave.shtml).
- A printable handout on Family Leave Insurance can be downloaded [here](https://www.nj.gov/labor/forms_pdfs/tdi/FLI_About.pdf).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance | Employer and HR Professional Toolkit

text:
Benefits of Programs  
- NJ Paid Family and Medical Leave, also known as Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance, supports employees and businesses.
- Employees often first learn about benefits from their employer, making it crucial for employers to have up-to-date information.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance | Employer and HR Professional Toolkit

text:
Toolkit Contents  
- 2023 Year-End Tax Statements available for download.
- Resources for employers:
- **Printable Handout with Tips for Employers**
- **Employer and HR Professional Slideshow**
- **Workplace Benefit Posters** (Required by law for covered employers)
- **Podcast Series** for information on programs and application processes

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance | Employer and HR Professional Toolkit

text:
Information on Job Protection  
- Temporary Disability Insurance and Family Leave Insurance are wage replacement programs and do not offer job protection.
- However, employer organizations may be covered by laws such as COVID-19 anti-retaliation, FMLA, NJFLA, or SAFE Act.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance | Employer and HR Professional Toolkit

text:
Employee Assistance  
- Direct employees to the appropriate information and benefit applications on the website.
- Share **Temporary Disability Insurance Handouts** and **Family Leave Insurance Handouts** with employees.

Approved Medical Practitioners and Healthcare Providers
Here you can find the medical practitioners approved by the division to submit medical information for both Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance.
- **Temporary Disability Insurance Approved Providers**
- Chiropractor
- Dentist
- Osteopath
- Podiatrist
- Medical Doctor
- Optometrist
- Psychologist
- Advanced Practice Nurse
- Advanced Practice Registered Nurse
- Certified Nurse Practitioner
- Clinical Nurse Specialist

- Medical information cannot be submitted by a: Professional counselor, Social worker (LCSW), Faith healer

- Psychologist

- Medical information cannot be submitted by a: Professional counselor, Faith healer

text:
Applying for Benefits When You Are Unemployed
- Are you unemployed, but no longer able or available for work due to your own physical or mental health condition, pregnancy, need for bonding or caregiving leave? You may be eligible for Disability During Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment benefits.
- Looking for Unemployment Insurance? Visit MyUnemployment.nj.gov  
Disability During Unemployment (DDU)
- If you have an illness, injury, pregnancy, or another physical or mental health condition and have not been working recently, you may be eligible for benefits under the Disability During Unemployment (DDU) program. Click to learn more about disability during unemployment.  
Family Leave During Unemployment (FLDU)
- If you need to bond with a new addition to your family or care for a loved one, but you haven't worked recently, you may be eligible for Family Leave During Unemployment (FLDU) benefits. Click here to learn about family leave during unemployment benefits.

text:
Ready to Start Your Bonding Leave?
There are two ways you can claim Family Leave Insurance:
1) TRANSITIONAL BONDING CLAIM: Claim your bonding benefits immediately after your pregnancy and recovery period (Temporary Disability Insurance) ends, with no interruption.
2) NEW BONDING CLAIM FOR THOSE WHO:
- received pregnancy disability benefits through private insurance/employer
- didn't receive pregnancy disability benefits at all or postponed their bonding leave to a later date making it non-transitional  
Choose which Family Leave path works best for you:
- Transitioning into bonding leave right after your NJ Temporary Disability claim ends?
[Transition into bonding (FL2)](link)
- Postponed your bonding leave or didn't receive NJ Temporary Disability benefits?
[Start a new application (FL1)]

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage  
Maternity Leave Coverage  
Are Temporary Disability benefits available for surrogates?
- An eligible birthing parent may receive Temporary Disability benefits for pregnancy and childbirth recovery.
- The parent must meet the minimum earnings requirement in New Jersey covered employment.
- Wages earned for being a surrogate may not be considered covered employment.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Are Temporary Disability benefits available for surrogates?

text:
Are Family Leave Insurance benefits available for surrogacy arrangements?
- Nonbirthing parent(s) may receive Family Leave Insurance benefits to bond with a new child within the first year of birth.
- Nonbirthing parent(s) may also receive Family Leave insurance benefits to care for a surrogate during pregnancy and childbirth recovery if they are considered family.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Are Family Leave Insurance benefits available for surrogacy arrangements?

text:
Can my employer require me to use paid time off (PTO) before receiving Temporary Disability benefits?
- Employers may require employees to take PTO before claiming Temporary Disability Insurance benefits if they separate NJ Earned Sick Leave from their PTO policy.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Can my employer require me to use paid time off (PTO) before receiving Temporary Disability benefits?

text:
Can I collect Temporary Disability Insurance benefits for my pregnancy?
- Eligibility for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits due to pregnancy is determined based on the same criteria as any other disability.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Can I collect Temporary Disability Insurance benefits for my pregnancy?

text:
When should I apply for Temporary Disability Insurance if I’m pregnant?
- File an application when stopped working and certified as unable to work due to pregnancy.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: When should I apply for Temporary Disability Insurance if I’m pregnant?

text:
How long can I collect Temporary Disability Insurance benefits for my pregnancy?
- Benefits are usually payable up to four weeks before the expected delivery date and up to six weeks after giving birth.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: How long can I collect Temporary Disability Insurance benefits for my pregnancy?

text:
Do I have to live in New Jersey to receive Temporary Disability Insurance benefits for pregnancy?
- Eligibility for benefits is based on working in New Jersey, not residency.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Do I have to live in New Jersey to receive Temporary Disability Insurance benefits for pregnancy?

text:
Why haven't I received my FL2 (New Mother Bonding Notice) yet?
- The FL2 is sent after confirming delivery information, and completing the Request to Claimant for Continued Claim Information.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Why haven't I received my FL2 (New Mother Bonding Notice) yet?

text:
Can I collect Temporary Disability Insurance benefits if my medical provider determines my work environment is harmful to my baby?
- Benefits are not payable for environmental risks if an individual is physically able to work.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Can I collect Temporary Disability Insurance benefits if my medical provider determines my work environment is harmful to my baby?

text:
Is job protection guaranteed during pregnancy and recovery with Temporary Disability Insurance or Family Leave Insurance?
- Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance do not guarantee job protection, but federal and state laws may provide job protection.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance FAQ: Maternity Leave Coverage
metadata.Header 3: Is job protection guaranteed during pregnancy and recovery with Temporary Disability Insurance or Family Leave Insurance?

Want to Extend or End Your Pregnancy Disability Claim?

metadata.Header 2: Do You Need to Download a 1099-G?

text:
Do You Need to Download a 1099-G?  
- You need to log in to your account to download a 1099-G form for your 2023 tax return if you received any of the following benefits in 2023:
- Family Leave Insurance benefits
- Family Leave During Unemployment Insurance benefits
- Disability During Unemployment Insurance benefits
- Benefits are federally taxable during the year that payments are issued, which may not always match up with when your leave occurred.
- If you filed an application for a period of leave in December 2023 but payments were not issued until January 2024, you do not need to download a 1099-G for your 2023 federal tax return. You will need to declare those benefits on your 2024 tax return.
- If you received ONLY Temporary Disability Insurance benefits, you will NOT have a 1099-G in your online account.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
How You’ll Get Your Money  
Step 1: Check Your Mail
- Once your application is approved, you'll be mailed a Money Network/My Banking Direct prepaid Visa debit card in a plain envelope with an Omaha, NE return address.
- Benefit payments are available from your debit card within three business days of the payment date.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Step 2: Activate Your Card
- Contact My Banking Direct toll-free at 888-292-0059 or visit mbd.everywherepaycard.com to activate your card.
- Services available include checking your balance, transferring funds, reporting a lost or stolen card, changing your PIN, and receiving information about transaction fees.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Tip
- Debit cards are valid for approximately six months after withdrawal of all funds. Keep the card for possible future benefits within this period.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Step 3: Get Your Money
- Your debit card can be used everywhere VISA debit cards are accepted, with no bank fees for purchases.
- Cash can be obtained from ATMs nationwide or tellers at VISA-accepting banks, though fees may apply.
- Use the Money Network mobile app to find surcharge-free ATMs and transfer funds to your primary banking account.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Additional Information
- For lost or damaged cards, call Money Network/My Banking Direct at 888-292-0059 for a replacement.

The Notice of Disability Benefits Charged or Credited  
Purpose of Notice
- Informs the employer that benefit payments have been charged to their disability experience rating account.
- Notice is received each time State Disability Insurance benefit payments are made to an employee.
- Includes employee's name, Social Security number, claim start date, payment period-ending date, amount charged, taxable amounts, taxes, and net amount paid.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Taxable Wages
- State Disability Insurance benefits are considered third-party sick pay.
- Portion attributable to the employer's contribution is considered taxable wages.
- Subject to Social Security, Medicare, and FUTA taxes.
- Worker's Social Security and Medicare contributions and federal income tax amounts deducted and deposited with the IRS.

text:
How Benefits Are Calculated
1. **Average Weekly Wage Calculation**:
- Base year earnings divided by the number of base weeks.
- Base week criteria:
- 2023 - $260 or more.
- 2024 - $283 or more.  
2. **Weekly Benefit Rate**:
- Claimants receive 85% of their average weekly wage.
- Maximum weekly benefit rates for 2023 and 2024.
- 2023 - $1,025 per week.
- 2024 - $1,055 per week.

- Inform after each segment for benefit continuation.

metadata.Header 1: Family Leave Insurance

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
FAQ: Family Leave Insurance  
- Family Leave Insurance provides New Jersey workers cash benefits for up to twelve weeks to bond with a newborn or newly placed adoptive, or foster child, to provide care for a seriously ill or injured loved one, or to handle matters related to domestic and/or sexual violence.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Before You File  
- How do I apply for Family Leave Insurance benefits?
- You can apply online, which is the easiest way to apply for benefits.
- You may also download, print, and fill out a paper application (FL-1) or fax it to the Division of Temporary Disability & Family Leave Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
After You Submit an Application  
- Who is eligible for Family Leave Insurance benefits?
- Any New Jersey worker who contributes to the state plan for Family Leave Insurance, or an approved private plan may be eligible.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Once You Receive a Decision  
- Do I have to live in New Jersey to receive Family Leave Insurance benefits?
- You may be eligible to receive benefits if you work in New Jersey, regardless of where you live.  
- Do I need to apply for all of my Family Leave benefits at once?
- You do not need to claim your Family Leave benefit days all at one time.
- You can claim benefits in one continuous period or on a day-by-day basis to suit your needs.  
- Can I claim a continuous period of leave for less than 12 weeks (84 days)?
- Yes, you may claim family leave for any length of time you need.  
- Can I collect Family Leave Insurance benefits to care for a loved one undergoing a gender affirmation procedure?
- Yes, as long as the medical provider certifies their need for your care.  
- I have returned to work after claiming family leave benefits. Can I claim additional benefits within my 12-month period?
- It depends on the number of days already claimed.  
- My child’s school has mandatory remote learning, or my child’s school or place of care is closed due to COVID-19, and I can’t work. Can I get Family Leave Insurance benefits for this?
- No. Mandatory remote learning is not a qualifying reason to receive Family Leave Insurance benefits.  
- Is there a time limit for applying for Family Leave Insurance benefits?
- You have 30 days from the first day of your leave to file your claim.  
- Do I need to notify my employer if I plan to apply for Family Leave Insurance benefits?
- Yes, depending on the type of claim.  
- Can my employer require me to use paid time off before receiving Family Leave benefits?
- Your employer cannot require you to use company paid time off.  
- I am a school employee on a school-wide recess. Can I receive Family Leave Insurance benefits?
- School employees on a recess cannot receive benefits.  
- What if I work a second job during school breaks?
- You may qualify for benefits using the wages from that other job.  
- I have to care for a family member who lives, but the answer seems to be cut off.  
For more FAQ details and information, please refer to the [official website](https://www.nj.gov/labor/Division of Temporary Disability (DTDI) and Family Leave Insurance (FLI)).# Family Leave Insurance FAQs

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Eligibility for Benefits
- **Out-of-state or out-of-country**: Eligibility for benefits is not affected by travel to care for a family member.
- **Taking Leave**: Benefits can be taken in one continuous period of up to 12 weeks or on an intermittent basis for up to 8 weeks.
- **Partner Leave**: Partners can stagger their leave periods to receive benefits at different times.
- **Certification and Payment**: Payment is conditional on certifying leave days and submitting necessary documentation.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Comparison with Other Acts
- **FLI vs. FMLA/NJFLA**: Family Leave Insurance and FMLA/NJFLA are separate programs with different provisions.
- **Job Protection**: While FLI does not guarantee job protection, FMLA/NJFLA may provide job security.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application and Benefits
- **Transition from Unemployment**: Benefits may be payable under the Family Leave During Unemployment program.
- **Funding**: The program is funded through worker payroll deductions with no employer contributions.
- **Pregnancy Transition**: Instructions for filing transitional bonding claims are provided by the Division of Temporary Disability.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Benefits Calculation and Duration
- **Benefit Calculation**: Average weekly wage determines benefit amount, capped at a maximum weekly benefit rate.
- **Benefit Amount**: Up to $1,025 per week in 2023 and $1,055 per week in 2024.
- **Maximum Duration**: Up to 12 weeks in a 12-month period for continuous leave, 8 weeks for intermittent leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Claim Management
- **Address Update**: Address changes must be notified in writing to the Division.
- **Form Requests**: Lost forms can be requested by calling the provided number.
- **Annual Entitlement**: Benefits can be applied for within the same annual period if entitlement is not maxed out.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Appeals and Taxation
- **Appeals**: Process for appealing a benefit determination is available.
- **Taxation**: Benefits are taxable income for federal purposes but not for New Jersey gross income tax.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Additional Resources
- **Debit Card Information**
- **Appeals Process**
- **11 Reasons Applications Are Denied**  
For more detailed information, including specific scenarios and additional queries, refer to the [Family Leave Insurance website](https://www.nj.gov/labor/fli/fli-index.html).# Job Protected?

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
FAQ: Temporary Disability Insurance  
Before You File
- Employers in New Jersey are required to have Temporary Disability Insurance for their employees.
- You can apply online or submit a paper application (DS-1) via mail or fax.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Who is eligible for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits?
- Any New Jersey worker contributing to the state plan or an employer's private plan.
- Minimum gross earnings requirements need to be met.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Who is eligible for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits?

text:
What are the Minimum Gross Earnings Requirements?
- Earnings reported for the five completed quarters prior to the disability.
- Determined by the base year and specific requirements based on timeframes.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: What are the Minimum Gross Earnings Requirements?

text:
Do I have to live in New Jersey to receive benefits?
- You may be eligible if you work in New Jersey, regardless of residency.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Do I have to live in New Jersey to receive benefits?

text:
Can my employer require PTO before benefits?
- Employers can require employees to use PTO based on NJ Earned Sick Leave law.
- Employers cannot require PTO accrued under the NJ Earned Sick Leave law before claiming benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Can my employer require PTO before benefits?

text:
Is there a time limit for applying for benefits?
- Application must be filed within 30 days of the disability.
- Late applications will require reasons and may result in reduced or denied benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Is there a time limit for applying for benefits?

text:
Is job protection guaranteed while receiving benefits?
- New Jersey Temporary Disability Insurance Law does not require job protection.
- Job protection rights may apply under the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Is job protection guaranteed while receiving benefits?

text:
Can Temporary Disability Insurance be applied more than once a year?
- No limit on the number of claims, must meet eligibility requirements each time.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Can Temporary Disability Insurance be applied more than once a year?

text:
Can benefits be collected for workplace injuries?
- If denied workers' compensation benefits, Temporary Disability Insurance may be applied for.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Can benefits be collected for workplace injuries?

text:
Can benefits be claimed for gender affirmation treatments?
- Yes, with medical certification of the necessity for leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Can benefits be claimed for gender affirmation treatments?

text:
Transitioning from Unemployment Insurance to DDU
- Available for those who become disabled after receiving Unemployment benefits.
- Process involves completing an application for Temporary Disability Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Transitioning from Unemployment Insurance to DDU

text:
Additional Notes
- Planned surgeries may not be processed in advance.
- The procedure for transitioning from Unemployment to Disability During Unemployment (DDU) benefits is outlined.
- Benefits may require medical documentation and proper certification.# Disability During Unemployment FAQs

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application Process
- **Temporary Disruption in Benefits:**
- New applications will take time to process, causing a temporary disruption in benefits.
- Retroactive payments are made by Disability During Unemployment benefits.  
- **Transition between Private and State Plan:**
- Exhausting benefits under a private plan does not qualify for state plan benefits.
- Consult local Social Security office for information on Social Security Disability benefits.  
- **Decision Timeline:**
- Applications are processed in the order received.
- Complete and accurate information speeds up the process.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Benefit Details
- **Commencement of Benefits:**
- Benefits start on the eighth day of disability.
- Waiting week is the initial seven-day period without benefits.  
- **Weekly Benefit Calculation:**
- Average weekly wage calculation based on base year earnings.
- Claimants receive 85% of average weekly wage, up to the maximum weekly benefit rate set annually.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Administrative Procedures
- **Address Change:**
- Update address online or via mail/fax.
- Include necessary details and follow submission instructions.  
- **Form Requests:**
- Access online if filed originally online.
- Request a new form by calling customer service.  
- **Medical Provider Visits:**
- Initial visit required within 10 days of disability onset.
- No set frequency of visits, but proof of disability may be requested periodically.  
- **Returning to Work:**
- Notify immediately of recovery or return to work.
- Follow specific instructions based on forms received.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Estate and Appeal Process
- **Estate Claiming Benefits:**
- Provide notarized documents to claim benefits on behalf of deceased claimant.  
- **Appeals Process:**
- Consult received decision for appeal rights and follow the outlined process.  
- **Impartial Medical Exam:**
- Mandatory state-appointed doctor exam for benefit validation.
- Failure to attend may halt benefit payments.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Taxation and Additional Information
- **Taxable Benefits:**
- Temporary Disability benefits are taxable as income.
- Federal income tax may be withheld if requested or submit IRS form W-4S.
- Garnishments and refunds may be deducted from benefits.  
- **Exhausted Benefits:**
- Explore alternative assistance programs if benefits are exhausted.  
- **Pregnancy Coverage:**
- Pregnancy-related disability eligibility aligns with standard criteria.
- Physician certification of disability is mandatory for pregnancy-related benefits.  
- **Applying for Pregnancy Benefits:**
- Advance application 60 days prior to leave.
- Timely completion and submission are crucial for benefit continuation.  
- **Duration of Pregnancy Benefits:**
- Benefits continue based on disability status and certification.  
For further clarification on specific forms or processes, refer to state guidelines and resources provided.# Pregnancy and Temporary Disability Insurance

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Time Frame for Benefits
- Up to four weeks before the expected delivery date
- Six to eight weeks after childbirth, depending on the delivery method
- If complications arise more than four weeks before the due date or longer than eight weeks postpartum, benefits may extend.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Eligibility for Benefits
- If the doctor certifies health risks in the work environment, benefits may not be payable.
- Exposure to environmental hazards without physical disability may lead to ineligibility for Temporary Disability Insurance but could qualify for Unemployment Insurance benefits.
- Benefits are granted if the individual is disabled.
- For instances related to the baby's health, one may apply for Family Leave Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Job Protection
- receiving Temporary Disability Insurance does not mandate job protection.
- Job security may be governed by the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Related Topics and Resources
- Debit Card Information
- Appealing a Decision
- Reasons for Application Denial
- The Waiting Week Explanation
- Printable Handout on Cash Benefits
- Information for Workers and Employers
- State Regulations and Contacts  
For more detailed information and resources, refer to the [New Jersey Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Website](https://www.nj.gov/labor/tdi/index.shtml).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Disability During Unemployment  
Have an illness, injury, pregnancy or other physical or mental health condition but haven't worked recently and/or are collecting Unemployment benefits? You may be eligible for Disability During Unemployment (DDU) benefits, a combination of Temporary Disability and Unemployment Insurance.  
Apply Online
- Start a new application
- Finish an application you started  
Manage an Existing Claim
- Access Claim Documents
- Download your 1099-G  
Learn About Disability During Unemployment (DDU) Benefits:
- **Before Applying**
- **How to Apply**
- **After Being Approved/Denied**
- **Download Forms**
- **Frequently Asked Questions About the Program**

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Have an illness, injury, pregnancy or other physical or mental health condition but haven't worked recently and/or are collecting Unemployment benefits? You may be eligible for Disability During Unemployment (DDU) benefits, a combination of Temporary Disability and Unemployment Insurance.

text:
Temporary Disability Benefits  
You may be eligible for Temporary Disability benefits through the Disability During Unemployment section if you become unable to work more than 14 days from your last day of work at an employer covered for New Jersey Temporary Disability Insurance (whether you are still employed or not). You may become unable to work due to:
- A physical or mental illness, (non-work related) injury or scheduled surgery.
- Pregnancy and childbirth recovery.
- An underlying health condition that makes you high risk for COVID-19, as certified by a licensed healthcare provider.  
How Much Do I Need to Earn to Qualify?
- **If You're Applying for Temporary Disability After Receiving Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits**
- **If You Did Not Collect Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits**  
When Will My Claim Start?
- **If You're Applying for Temporary Disability After Applying For Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits**
- **If You Did Not Collect Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits**  
How Much Will I Receive?
- **If You're Applying for Temporary Disability After Receiving Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits**
- **If You Did Not Collect Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits**

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: You may be eligible for Temporary Disability benefits through the Disability During Unemployment section if you become unable to work more than 14 days from your last day of work at an employer covered for New Jersey Temporary Disability Insurance (whether you are still employed or not). You may become unable to work due to:

text:
Dependency Benefits:
- If you have not already qualified for the maximum weekly benefit rate if/when your claim is approved, you may be entitled to additional benefits as a dependency benefit. Dependency benefits are payable at 7% of your basic weekly benefit rate for your first dependent and then at 4% for each of the next two dependents (you may claim no more than three dependents). You will be sent instructions on how to qualify and apply for dependency benefits after you file your claim.  
*If your spouse or civil union partner is unemployed and claimed*# Temporary Disability During Unemployment in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Claim Information
- If your children are dependents on their Unemployment claim, you cannot claim them on your Disability During Unemployment claim.
- Maximum benefits you can receive combined across programs (Unemployment, Disability During Unemployment, and Family Leave During Unemployment) is one and one-half times the maximum benefit amount of your initial Unemployment claim.
- The maximum benefit amount only applies to standard Unemployment benefits, unaffected by pandemic-related benefit extensions.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Benefits Calculation
- If you did not collect Unemployment or Family Leave During Unemployment benefits, you may receive benefits for each base week worked in your base year period, up to a maximum of 26 weeks.
- In 2024, a base week is any week with earnings of $283 or more.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Funding
- Both workers and employers in New Jersey contribute to Temporary Disability Insurance coverage.
- Workers contribute 0.14% on the first $151,900 in covered wages for 2022.
- Employers' contribution rate varies between 0.10% to 0.75% of the wage cap, with specific amounts for 2023 and 2024.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application Process
- You can apply for Disability During Unemployment benefits online, via mail, or by fax.
- Required information includes personal details, medical provider information, dates of employment, and expected recovery date.
- Medical provider certification is essential for the application process.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application Tips
- Applying online is recommended for faster processing.
- Provide accurate and complete information to prevent delays.
- Avoid submitting multiple claims through different channels.
- Utilize mobile apps for document submission.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
After Applying
- Temporary denial upon application submission may occur to route the claim to the correct section.
- Claim approval duration varies based on existing Unemployment or Family Leave status.
- Retroactive payments are made for delays, especially for transitioning from Unemployment or Family Leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Forms and Payments
- Additional questionnaires may be required if no previous Unemployment or Family Leave claim exists.
- Benefit payments are typically issued through prepaid debit cards from Money Network/My Banking Direct.
- Direct Deposit options may be available depending on previous claim setup.# Disability During Unemployment Insurance

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Payment Information
- Claim eligibility results in weekly payments.
- Payments may cover periods longer than a week.
- Full weeks run from Sunday through Saturday.
- Federal income tax not withheld unless requested.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Continuing to Receive Benefits
- Proof of continuing disability may be required.
- A form called Claim for Continued Benefits is used.
- Additional benefits require completion of the form.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Reasons for Benefit Reduction/Denial
- Benefits not payable for periods less than seven days.
- Medical care must be ongoing from a licensed professional.
- Ineligibility if receiving other state or federal benefits.
- Ineligibility during full salary/paid time off periods.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Tax Information
- Benefits not taxable for NJ state income but are for federal tax.
- Option to request 10% federal tax withholding.
- Form 1099-G available annually for tax purposes.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Appeals
- Appeal rights statement provided with written determinations.
- Appeal must be filed within specified timeframe.
- Appeals hearing notification sent by mail.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Independent Medical Examinations
- Routine physical examinations may be required.
- No charge for the examination.
- Results kept confidential.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Forms
- Notification of Information Change form mailed to update details.
- Claim for Continued Benefits form for additional medical certification.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Transitioning from Unemployment to DDU Benefits
- Stop claiming weekly Unemployment benefits.
- Apply for Temporary Disability Insurance.
- Temporary denial while transitioning reflected as "Ineligible" online.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Transitioning from Unemployment to DDU Benefits

text:
Returning to Unemployment after Recovery
- Reopen Unemployment claim if criteria are met.
- Maximum benefit limit must not be exceeded.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Referral to DDU Section
- Application may be referred to DDU regardless of current employment status.
- Criteria: Disability period started more than 14 days after last work day or pay.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Additional Form Requirements
- Questionnaire may be sent to gather Unemployment criteria information.
- Ensure completion of all questions for eligibility review.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Medical Information
- Temporary Disability benefit application requires input from healthcare provider.# Disability During Unemployment Benefits FAQ

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Form ID Number
- Unique form ID number required for submitting a statement.
- Responsibility to provide the number to submit benefits.
- Completion of required parts in paper benefit application.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Payment Period
- Benefits issued when disabled and under medical care within 10 days.
- Payment only for the period of disability and care.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Medical Certification
- No set requirement for frequency of medical provider visits.
- Periodic proof from doctor may be requested to continue benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Benefit Rate
- Benefits calculated at 60% of average weekly wage.
- Rate determined by Unemployment Insurance law.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Eligibility and Disqualifications
- Disqualifications from Unemployment Insurance apply to Disability During Unemployment.
- Eligibility criteria must be met, including job loss through no fault of own.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Difference in Benefit Amounts
- DDU benefit amount lower due to inclusion/exclusion of different earnings.
- Calculation based solely on relevant earnings for the DDU program.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Maximum Benefit Weeks
- Maximum of 39 benefit weeks when transitioning from one program to another.
- Maximum Benefit Amount formula based on individual’s employment history.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Claim Continuation
- Claim remains active for one year from initial claim date.
- Review and establishment of new claim if still disabled after benefit year ends.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Next Steps after Claim Exhaustion
- Options after exhausting DDU claim include applying for long term Social Security Disability benefits.
- Additional available programs for assistance provided.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Family Leave Insurance  
General Information
- Family Leave Insurance provides New Jersey workers cash benefits to bond with a newborn, newly adopted, newly placed foster child, or to provide care for a seriously ill or injured loved one.
- Some employers provide Family Leave Insurance through a plan with a private insurance carrier.
- Coverage under the State’s family leave program varies by employer.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How to Apply for Benefits
- Apply online, by mail, or by fax.
- Instructions included in the application should be carefully read before completion.
- Ensure the form is signed and dated if filing by mail or fax.
- Application can be started up to 60 days in advance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How to Receive Benefits Quickly
- Apply online for faster processing.
- Provide medical provider with instructions online for family caregiving.
- Fill out the application completely and accurately.
- Include Social Security number on all correspondence.
- Avoid faxing pictures of documents, use free mobile apps for submissions.
- Be prepared to receive payments through a prepaid debit card.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Who Qualifies for State Benefits
- New Jersey workers who have paid into the program through employment.
- Minimum gross earnings requirements must be met.
- Exclusions include federal government employees, out-of-state employees, faith-based organizations, and non-employees like contractors.
- If unsure about coverage, it is encouraged to apply.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify
- Earnings reported for 5 completed quarters prior to the week leave began are considered during review.
- Qualification for 2023: 20 weeks of work with a minimum of $260 weekly, or $13,000 in combined earnings in base year.
- Qualification for 2024: 20 weeks of work with a minimum of $283 weekly, or $14,200 in combined earnings in base year.
- Base year period is determined by the date of application for benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How Benefits Are Calculated
- Average weekly wage calculation:
- Divide base year earnings by the number of base weeks
- "Base week" earnings threshold for 2023 is $260, and for 2024, it is $283
- Weekly benefit rate:
- Claimants receive 85% of their average weekly wage, up to the maximum weekly benefit rate
- Maximum weekly benefit rates for 2023 and 2024 are provided
- Example calculation for benefits based on reported wages for specific quarters

- Options for claiming benefits:

- Non-continuous (intermittent) leave for up to 56 individual days (8 weeks)

text:
Continuous and Non-Continuous Leave Payments
- For Continuous Leave:
- Payments are typically issued every two weeks after the initial payment.
- There is a one-week lag for processing time.
- Payment amount may vary for each period.
- For Non-Continuous Leave:
- Each day of benefits paid equals one-seventh (1/7) of the weekly benefit rate.
- Funds should be available on the debit card within three business days of the payment date.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Informing Your Employer
- For Continuous Leave:
- Notification to the employer must be given 30 days before starting the leave.
- For Bonding in Separate Periods:
- Notification to the employer must be given 15 days before each period of leave, or benefit entitlement may be reduced by 14 days.
- Importance of Communication:
- Encouragement to keep the employer informed to allow for preparation and job protection insights.

Coverage and Qualifications
- Contact your employer for information on coverage or apply directly with a private insurance carrier.
- Qualifications:

- Need to have paid into the program through employment and meet gross earnings requirements.
- Exceptions: Federal government employees, out-of-state employees, faith-based organizations, non-employee workers.
- Employers must set up payroll contributions for covered employees, but if contributions have not been made in error, applicants are encouraged to apply.
- Those recently unemployed may still be eligible for benefits.
- Family Leave During Unemployment section processes applications accordingly.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Job Protection Information  
Temporary Disability Insurance and Family Leave Insurance
- These are wage replacement programs and do not provide job protection.
- However, during the benefit period, job protection may be available under federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), New Jersey Family Leave Act (NJFLA), or the New Jersey Security and Financial Empowerment Act (SAFE).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Temporary Disability Insurance and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)
- Allows eligible employees of covered employers to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for specified family and medical reasons.
- Provides continuation of group health insurance coverage during the leave.
- For more information: [FMLA Information](https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/fmla)

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)

text:
New Jersey Family Leave Act (NJFLA)
- Eligible employees of covered employers can have up to 12 weeks of job-protected leave to care for a loved one within a two-year period.
- More information available at [njcivilrights.gov](https://www.nj.gov/labor/worker-protections/myworkrights/retaliation.shtml)

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
New Jersey Security and Financial Empowerment Act (SAFE)
- Provides up to 20 days of unpaid, job protected leave related to sexual and domestic violence matters.
- For more information about NJ SAFE Act, [click here](https://www.nj.gov/labor/worker-protections/myworkrights/retaliation.shtml)

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: New Jersey Security and Financial Empowerment Act (SAFE)

text:
Protection Against Retaliation
- If an employer retaliates for taking or seeking to take Temporary Disability or Family Leave Insurance benefits, employees have the right to take legal action.
- Learn more at [NJ Worker Rights Retaliation](https://www.nj.gov/labor/worker-protections/myworkrights/retaliation.shtml)

text:
Information for Healthcare Providers  
- **Helpful Resources**
- **Submit a Medical Certification**  
If your patient or their caregiver applied online for benefits, they will provide you with printed instructions for completing your medical statement (form M-01) online.
If they have been approved for Temporary Disability benefits and wish to extend their claim further, they will provide you with printed instructions for completing your medical extension (form M-03) online.
These instructions provide the claimant's unique Form ID, which you will need to complete your medical certification using our online system.
The information you submit is encrypted, and the system meets all state-mandated security standards. You’ll get immediate confirmation that we received your statement.  
- **For Temporary Disability Claims**
- Medical statement (M-01) for temporary disability claims
- Medical extension (M-03) for temporary disability claims
- **For Family Leave Claims**
- Medical statement (M-01) for family leave caregiving claims  
For more information, visit the [Department of Labor and Workforce Development website](https://www.nj.gov/labor/).

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
How to Submit Wage Information  
Overview
The Division reviews the employee's quarterly earnings to approve benefit applications for both Temporary Disability Insurance and Family Leave Insurance. If there is insufficient information for approval, employers may be required to provide wage information.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Notifications
- Employers will receive a request for wage information (form E-10) or additional wage information (form E-20) by mail.
- Prompt completion and return of the form are necessary to determine the claim.
- Failure to comply may result in benefits denial and a monetary penalty.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Submission Process
- Faxed submissions: 609-984-4138
- Mailed to:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
PO Box 387
Trenton, New Jersey 08625-0387

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Verification
- Applications are cross-checked with the wage record maintained by the Division of Employer Accounts.
- Employers may receive a confirmation form if the application is submitted before the employee stops working.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Compliance and Penalties
- Employers must provide requested wage information promptly.
- Failure to comply within 10 days may result in a $250 penalty.
- Clarify if the individual is not or was not your employee to avoid penalties.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Helpful Tips
- Complete and return the Form E-20 within 10 days of mailing without post-dating.
- Include the employee's Social Security number, date, and signature on all pages.
- Provide exact dates, especially the last day worked.
- Specify any payments made during the disability period.
- Attach additional information if necessary and update incorrect address on return.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Expectation vs. Reality: When Limitations Affect Your Disability Benefits  
Reasons for Benefits Not Being Approved:  
- Your disability does not exceed seven days in length.
- You have already received 26 weeks of benefits for this period of disability.
- You became disabled more than 14 days after your last day of work.
- You are not currently receiving medical care from an approved medical provider.
- The disability resulted from the commission of a criminal act or was self-inflicted.
- You were discharged by your most recent employer for gross misconduct connected with the work.
- You worked and received wages after the period of disability began.
- Your disability began during a labor dispute at your most recent place of employment.
- You are still receiving wages that exceed your regular weekly wages immediately prior to the onset of the disability.
- You received other benefits such as Unemployment Insurance, Social Security Disability, or workers' compensation benefits.
- You are receiving a pension from your most recent employer.
- You owe a garnishment for child support.
- You have an overpayment from a previous disability or family leave claim.
- You filed your application more than 30 days after the start of your disability claim without good cause.
keywords: limitations affect your disability benefits reasons

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions  
Temporary Disability Insurance  
Can I certify a patient's need for gender affirmation procedures?  
Medical providers can certify a patient’s need for gender affirmation procedures, including but not limited to, top surgery, bottom surgery, facial feminization or masculinization, voice surgery, tracheal shaving, etc. Medical providers can also certify the need for a patient’s loved one to help them recover. The definition of a loved one is generous.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Can I certify a patient's need for gender affirmation procedures?

text:
Can I charge a fee for completing my patient’s Temporary Disability paperwork?  
No. The N.J.S.A. 12:18-1.6 prohibits charging a fee to complete Temporary Disability forms.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Can I charge a fee for completing my patient’s Temporary Disability paperwork?

text:
Is it safe and secure to file my patient’s medical information online?  
Yes. Precautions are taken to keep the information that you provide in the online application private and secure. The online application uses a secure connection and the data submitted is encrypted.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Is it safe and secure to file my patient’s medical information online?

text:
If my patient has a planned/scheduled surgery date, can I fill out their paperwork ahead of time?  
No. A disability claim cannot be filed until the period of disability actually begins.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: If my patient has a planned/scheduled surgery date, can I fill out their paperwork ahead of time?

text:
Do I need to have seen my patient on the first day of their disability period?  
No. You do not have to physically treat the patient on the same day they became disabled. You must be treating the patient within 10 days from the start of their disability period.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Do I need to have seen my patient on the first day of their disability period?

text:
Family Leave Insurance  
What date on the medical certificate drives the first day of Family Leave?  
The start of the Family Leave claim is the first date that care is provided to your patient. The patient’s condition may be preexisting, but the caregiver’s claim is specific to when they stopped working to care for their family member.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: What date on the medical certificate drives the first day of Family Leave?

text:
Is pregnancy a valid condition that may require care from a family member?  
Yes, pregnancy is a condition that may require care from a family member.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Is pregnancy a valid condition that may require care from a family member?

text:
Can I charge a fee for completing my patient’s caregiver’s Family Leave Insurance paperwork?  
No. The N.J.S.A. 12:18-1.6 prohibits charging a fee to complete Family Leave Insurance forms.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Can I charge a fee for completing my patient’s caregiver’s Family Leave Insurance paperwork?

text:
Is it safe and secure to file my patient’s medical information online?  
Yes. Precautions are taken to keep the information that you provide in the online application private and secure. The online application uses a secure connection, and the data submitted is encrypted.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Is it safe and secure to file my patient’s medical information online?

text:
Is the Division of Temporary Disability Insurance exempt from HIPAA regulations?  
The NJ Temporary Disability Benefits Program is not a “covered entity” under the Federal Health Information Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). All medical records of the Division, except to the extent necessary for the proper administration of the Temporary Disability Benefits Law are confidential and are not open to public inspection.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Is the Division of Temporary Disability Insurance exempt from HIPAA regulations?

text:
Why am I having trouble submitting my patient’s medical information online?  
There are various reasons the online medical application may not allow you to proceed. You should be aware that you may only complete your patient’s medical statement online while their caregiver’s claim is status pending. Once an application for benefits is either approved or denied, information can no longer be submitted online. In that case, you can submit medical information by faxing or mailing to the division part C of the paper application. Another reason you may have trouble accessing the online medical application is that the claimant may have provided you the incorrect Form ID.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Healthcare Providers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Why am I having trouble submitting my patient’s medical information online?

2024 Employee Contribution Rate

- FLI: Employees will contribute 0.09% of the first $161,400 in covered wages.
- The maximum FLI worker contribution for 2024 is $145.26.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
About the Program
- NJ Temporary Disability Insurance provides cash benefits to employees in New Jersey who are unable to work due to various conditions.
- It includes pregnancy/childbirth recovery.
- [Download a printable handout about the program](link).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Covered Employees and Employers
- Employers must participate in State public insurance programs and deduct payroll taxes for employees.
- Employers may opt for coverage through a private insurance plan meeting NJ requirements.
- Temporary Disability Insurance is optional for local governments.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
The Employer's Role
- Employers must display posters, provide written notice, report quarterly earnings, and monitor benefits issued to employees.
- They are responsible for reporting the taxable portion of Temporary Disability benefits on the employee's W-2.
- Employers are not required to complete an "employer portion" of the application.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Paid Time Off and Temporary Disability Insurance
- Employers may require employees to take paid time off before Temporary Disability benefits under certain circumstances.
- The NJ Earned Sick Leave law requirements can impact this.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

4. Scenario 4: State of NJ employees may have specific sick time use requirements.

text:
Additional Assistance
- Employers may be contacted for more information if needed to approve a claim.
- Forms like E-10 or E-20 may be sent to request additional information.# Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Program in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Required Wage and Employment Information
- To determine a claim, complete and return the form promptly.
- Failure to provide information can lead to benefits denial and a monetary penalty.
- Information requested from an employer can include:
- Federal employment identification numbers
- Paid time off details
- Employee's last date of work
- Confirmation of valid wages

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Reporting Temporary Disability Benefits
- Year-end statements available online for employers in January.
- Only a portion of benefits are taxable by the federal government.
- Employers must report taxable information on the employee’s W-2.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Funding the Program
- New Jersey workers and employers contribute to funding the program.
- Employer contribution rates vary between 0.10% to 0.75%.
- Contribution amounts based on employee earnings, with taxable wage cap changes annually.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Minimum Gross Earnings Requirements
- Determining eligibility is based on gross earnings from the previous base year.
- Specific work requirements for 2023 and 2024.
- Claim date and corresponding base year quarters for determination.

text:
Reporting Incorrect Payments
- Incorrect payments should be reported immediately to the Division by calling the customer service center at (609) 292-7060 or by faxing a corrected statement (including the employee's Social Security number) to (609) 984-4138.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Requesting Additional Information
- If more information is needed to approve a claim, wage information may be requested.
- Employers may receive a request for information (form E-10) or a request for additional wage information (form E-20) by mail.
- Failure to provide requested information promptly can lead to benefit denial and penalties.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Information Requested from Employers
- Federal employment identification numbers
- Paid time off, vacation, or sick time taken
- Any intermittent work days
- Employee's last date of work
- Validation of wages
- Wages paid during the family leave period

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Minimum Gross Earnings Requirement  
Qualification Criteria
- 20 weeks of work minimum, earning at least $260 weekly or a combined total of $13,000 in the base year for 2023.
- For 2024, the requirement is at least $283 weekly or a combined total of $14,200 in the base year.
keywords: minimum gross earnings requirement qualification criteria

metadata.Header 1: Minimum Gross Earnings Requirement

text:
Calculation Periods
- 2023 calculations based on earnings from October 1, 2022, to September 30, 2023.
- 2024 calculations based on earnings from January 1, 2023, to December 31, 2023.

metadata.Header 1: Minimum Gross Earnings Requirement

text:
Benefits Calculation Process  
Average Weekly Wage Determination
- Divide base year earnings by the number of base weeks.
- A "base week" requires earnings of $260 or more in 2023 and $283 or more in 2024.
keywords: benefits calculation process average weekly wage determination

metadata.Header 1: Benefits Calculation Process

text:
Maximum Weekly Benefit Rate
- Claimants receive 85% of their average weekly wage, up to the maximum weekly benefit rate set for the calendar year.
- Maximum rates are $1,025 per week in 2023 and $1,055 per week in 2024.

metadata.Header 1: Benefits Calculation Process

text:
Example: Calculation for Steve
- Average weekly wage calculation based on earnings in the first four quarters.
- Weekly benefit rate and daily benefit rate determined accordingly.

metadata.Header 1: Benefits Calculation Process

text:
Funding the Program  
Worker Contributions
- The program is funded solely by worker payroll deductions, with no employer contributions.
- Contributions for 2023 and 2024 based on covered wages up to the wage cap.

metadata.Header 1: Funding the Program

text:
Bonding Claims  
Eligibility
- Claimants can receive benefits to bond with a child within 12 months of birth, adoption, or placement.
- Days can be taken continuously for 12 weeks or individually up to eight weeks.

metadata.Header 1: Bonding Claims

text:
Care Claims  
Eligibility Criteria
- Benefits available for individuals caring for family members with serious health conditions.
- Leave can be taken continuously or on a day-to-day basis within a 12-month period.

metadata.Header 1: Care Claims

text: Definition of "Family Member" and "Serious Health Condition"

metadata.Header 1: Care Claims
metadata.Header 2: Definition of "Family Member" and "Serious Health Condition"

text:
Medical Professional's Role
- Determines the need for physical care or emotional support from a family member.
- Medical information authorization required for benefit application.

metadata.Header 1: Medical Professional's Role

text:
Program Overview  
Temporary Disability Benefits Law
- Employers have the option to establish private plans for disability or family leave insurance.
- Private plans must meet state-mandated provisions and approval requirements.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Private Plan Operations
- Responsible for approving and overseeing private plan policies.
- Private plans must offer benefits equal to or better than the State Plan.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Plan Establishment and Approval  
Approval Process
- Private plans can be established through insurance companies or as self-insured plans.
- Approval by the Department of Banking and Insurance and Private Plan Operations is required.  
---  
This is the structured content provided in Markdown format.# Private Plan Operations and Compliance

metadata.Header 1: Plan Establishment and Approval

text:
Modifying An Approved Private Plan
All modifications to an approved private plan must be approved by Private Plan Operations. Reasons for modifying a private plan include:
- Changing insurance carriers
- Changing the class of employees covered
- Modifying eligibility requirements
- Changing benefits  
For further clarifications on required modifications, contact the Private Plan Unit.

metadata.Header 1: Plan Establishment and Approval

text:
Terminating An Existing Private Plan
A private plan may be terminated by:
1. The employer:
- Must request termination in writing
- Effective date is 30 days after the postmark date
- Employer must include the NJ Employer Identification Number
- Send termination request to the Private Plan Compliance Section
- Upon termination, employer reverts to State Plan  
2. The insurer:
- Termination requires written notice to Private Plan Operations
- Advance notice varies based on reason for termination
- Employees are covered by the state plan after termination  
3. The covered workers:
- A petition signed by 10% of employees is required
- Workers vote on terminating the plan  
4. The Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance:
- May immediately terminate a private plan under just cause

metadata.Header 1: Plan Establishment and Approval

text:
Approved Insurance Companies
The following companies are approved to provide short-term group disability coverage in New Jersey. Private plans must use these companies for coverage:  
- List of Approved Companies

metadata.Header 1: Plan Establishment and Approval

text:
Private Plan Claims Processing
The Claims Review Unit oversees private plan claims processing. Claimants must be notified in writing of a denial and their right to appeal. The appeal process, under one year, is managed by the Private Plan Hearing Officer.

metadata.Header 1: Plan Establishment and Approval

text:

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
How The Employer Role Has Changed  
Your Role in the Application Process
- The role of the employer has changed in the application process.
- Employers may not be as involved as they were in the past in submitting their employees' applications, but their role as a reliable resource is now more important than ever.
- Employee claims are now calculated based on reported earnings from the previous calendar quarters, rather than the weekly earnings immediately before their leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How The Employer Role Has Changed
metadata.Header 3: Your Role in the Application Process

text:
Assistance Required
- Employers may be required to provide information if there is not enough data to approve a claim based on reported earnings.
- Employers may receive a request for information (form E-10) or request for additional wage information (form E-20) in such cases.
- Failure to provide the necessary information promptly can lead to denial of benefits and penalties.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How The Employer Role Has Changed

text:
Frequently Asked Questions
- **Do employees need to print the E01-Employer Statement instructional notice?**
- No, the new application only requires information from the employee.
- **What are the employer responsibilities?**
- Employers need to monitor benefits issued to employees and ensure accuracy.
- **Can employers assist employees in completing applications?**
- Employers are encouraged to assist employees in completing employment-related information.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How The Employer Role Has Changed

text:
Monitoring Benefits Issued
- Employers should review notices for Temporary Disability benefits and ensure accuracy.
- Employers will receive a "Notice of Eligible Determinations" for approved claims.
- Employers are advised to keep track of benefits issued.
- Employers should report any discrepancies immediately.
- Employers cannot view employees' benefits online currently.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How The Employer Role Has Changed

text:
Incorrect Information Reporting
- Employers should report any incorrect information on employee claims promptly.
- There are specific notification requirements for employees taking family leave.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?  
If your work is considered any of the unique employment situations below, your eligibility may be impacted, and your claim may require further review.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?

text:
Limited Liability Company (LLC)  
Limited liability companies are hybrid entities that combine the characteristics of a corporation and a partnership or sole proprietorship. LLCs file one of three types of Federal Income Tax Forms, dictating their type of LLC and coverage under Temporary Disability and Family Leave program.  
LLC Types:  
- **Sole Proprietorship (Filing a form 1040C with the Federal IRS):**
- If you are the owner of a sole proprietorship, you are **not covered** for Temporary Disability or Family Leave Insurance.
- If you are the owner's spouse, parent, or child (under the age of 18), you are **not covered** for Temporary Disability or Family Leave Insurance.
- If you do not fit any of the relationships listed above, your employment is covered for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance, and you may be eligible for benefits.  
- **Membership/Partnership (Filing a form 1065 with the Federal IRS):**
- If you are a member or partner of a membership/partnership LLC, you are **not covered** for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance.
- If you are not a member or partner of that LLC, then you are covered for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance and may be eligible for benefits.  
- **Incorporation (Filing a form 1120 with the Federal IRS):**
- If your LLC is incorporated, then all employees are covered for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance and may be eligible for benefits. Designations like INC, PC, PA, and NA indicate a corporation, where all officers should be considered employees and may be eligible for benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?

text:
Independent Contractor  
Independent Contractors are **not covered** for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance. Misclassification may deny benefits and protections such as Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?

text:
Gross Misconduct  
Gross Misconduct occurs when a worker is discharged for committing an act punishable as a crime of the first, second, third, or fourth degree under the **“New Jersey Code of Criminal Justice”**, N.J.S.A., 2C:1-1, et. If gross misconduct was committed, you will be disqualified from receiving Temporary Disability or Family Leave benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?

text:
Multi-State Employment  
Some positions require work in multiple locations throughout the day. Employment jurisdiction should be under the state where the centralized hub is located or where orders are received. If the central hub is in New Jersey, the employee may be eligible for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?

text:
Elected Officials  
Elected officials' positions are **not considered covered employment** for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance. If attending meetings regarding elected positions while claiming benefits, the worker cannot receive benefits for those meeting days.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Unique Employment: Am I Covered for Benefits?

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage  
Information for Workers
When You're Pregnant or Just Had a Baby  
Working mothers have a lot on their minds, whether they're pregnant or have just welcomed a new baby. Our two programs can help make this time of transition a little easier. **Temporary Disability** provides cash benefits for expectant mothers when they need to stop working before giving birth, and while recovering afterward. **Family Leave** provides cash benefits after the recovery period so new mothers can bond with their babies during the first year. In addition, your job may be protected under state and federal job protection laws. Learn more about how these programs and laws work together [here](https://www.state.nj.us/nj/family/temporary-disability).
