metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage

text:
The New Maternity Coverage Timeline Tool
Try it now

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage
metadata.Header 3: The New Maternity Coverage Timeline Tool

text:
Here’s How to Get Started:
1. **Plan Ahead**: To help understand your eligibility for cash benefits and job protection before your leave begins, read our handout on benefits and protections for new and expecting parents who work in NJ.
2. **Watch Our Video Tutorials**: Watch our step-by-step guides for completing an online application for Temporary Disability and/or Family Leave insurance. They'll walk you through each question with detailed instructions. Plus, you'll get helpful tips along the way.
3. **Apply Online When You Stop Working**: Apply for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits after your doctor certifies that you're disabled due to pregnancy, and you stop working. If you don't already have an account for our secure online system, click [here](https://www.state.nj.us/myunemployment/) and follow the prompts from the "First Time User?" button.
4. **Print Instruction Forms**: After your parts of the application are complete, you'll be prompted to print instructions with a unique Online Form ID number. Give them to your healthcare provider so they can complete their part online.
5. **If Approved, Access Your Funds**: If approved, we'll mail you a debit card to access your benefit payments. For more information about how the debit card works, click [here](https://www.nj.gov/labor/tdi/tdiindex.html).
6. **Notify Us When You Deliver**: We need to know your delivery information so you can start getting Family Leave Insurance benefits for bonding after you recover from delivery. Notify us by completing the form P30 sent to you in the mail.
7. **Receive Benefits for Bonding**: After your recovery period (Temporary Disability) ends, you can receive Family Leave Insurance benefits in a consecutive twelve-week period, or 56 individual days throughout your baby's first year.
8. **Prepare for Tax Time**: It's your employer's responsibility to report your Temporary Disability Insurance benefits on your W-2 as Third-Party Sick Pay or Other Wages. If you have questions at tax time, talk to your employer. For Family Leave Insurance benefits, you'll need to download a 1099-G in January for the prior year.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage

text:
General Information
- Temporary Disability for Pregnancy
- Family Leave for Newborn Bonding
- **Maternity Leave FAQ**:
- **Cash Benefits and Job Protections for Expectant Parents**
- **Cash Benefits**: Temporary Disability Insurance typically provides 10-12 weeks of cash benefits for when you need to stop working during your pregnancy and while recovering from child birth. Family Leave Insurance provides up to 12 weeks of cash benefits for time taken off from work to bond with your new child before your baby's first birthday.
- **Job Protection**: Federal Family & Medical Leave Act (FMLA) provides up to 12 weeks of unpaid job-protected leave to care for yourself before and after childbirth and to bond with your new child. Enforced by the US Department of Labor. NJ Family Leave Act (NJFLA) provides up to 12 weeks of unpaid job-protected leave to bond with your new child. Enforced by NJ Division on Civil Rights. Take up to 12 weeks of FMLA for pregnancy/recovery and/or a related serious health condition and up to 12 weeks of NJFLA for bonding, for a total of up to 24 weeks of job protection. Please note that the NJ Department of Labor does not enforce these job protection laws. Learn more about how these cash benefits and job protections for parents work together [here](https://www.state.nj.us/nj/family/temporary-disability).
- **Pregnancy**: Covered the Same Way as a Disability

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage

text:
How to Apply
Apply for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits only when you have stopped working and your doctor certifies that you are unable to work due to your pregnancy. You can apply for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits [online](https://www.state.nj.us/myunemployment/), in the mail, or by fax. Instructions are included on the application. Read all the instructions carefully before completing the application. If filing by mail or fax, don’t forget to sign and date the form. When you apply for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits, we’ll need information from you, and your medical provider. It is your responsibility to have all this information – including the medical provider part – submitted to us online, by mail, or by fax.  
**This is the information we need to complete your application:**
From you:
- Your Social Security number, contact information, and date of birth
- The date you became disabled
- Contact information for the medical provider who treated you within 10 days of the first day you were unable to work
- Dates of any emergency/urgent care treatment or hospitalizations
- Dates you worked for any employers in the last 18 months, the employers’ contact information, and the address(es) where you worked
- Dates of any paid time off or other benefits you received after the last day you worked
- The date when you expect to recover and return to work (or the date you recovered and returned to work)
From your doctor:
- A medical certification to confirm the period you are unable to work  
When you complete your part online, you will get a unique Online Form ID number to give to your medical provider. They will use this number to submit their part to us online. You will be prompted to print out (or save as a PDF file) a page that has your unique Online Form ID number, along with instructions for your medical provider to follow. If you do not have access to a printer when initially filing your application, you have a fourteen day window to return and print the instructions when a printer is available. You can do so by clicking Access claim documents at the top of this page. If planning ahead, you may start your online application up to 60 days in advance. To avoid deletion of your draft.# Application Process

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage

text:
Timeframes
- Within 14 days of starting the application, provide all information and confirm your claim.
- Within 14 days after the start of your leave, certify and file your claim.
- If applying after your leave begins, you have 30 days from your first day of leave to file your application.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage

text:
Tips for Receiving Benefits Quickly
- Apply online for faster processing.
- Instruct medical providers to complete their sections online.
- Provide instructions to medical providers as they are not automatically notified.
- Fill out the application completely and accurately.
- Include Social Security number on all correspondence.
- Avoid faxing pictures of documents; use mobile apps for digitization.
- Be prepared to receive payments through prepaid debit cards.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Maternity Coverage

text:
Qualification for State Benefits  
Who Qualifies
- Most New Jersey workers are encouraged to apply.
- Exemptions include specific categories of workers like federal government employees and out-of-state employees.

metadata.Header 1: Qualification for State Benefits

text:
Minimum Earnings Requirements
- To qualify for Temporary Disability Insurance, certain gross earnings requirements must be met.
- Earnings for the base year determine eligibility for benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Qualification for State Benefits

text:
Alternate Base Years
- Workers who don't qualify with the standard base year can have alternate base years calculated.

metadata.Header 1: Qualification for State Benefits

text:
Benefit Calculation  
Average Weekly Wage
- Calculated by dividing base year earnings by the number of base weeks.
- Determines the weekly benefit rate, capped at the maximum weekly benefit rate set for the calendar year.

metadata.Header 1: Benefit Calculation

text:
Duration of Benefits
- Typically payable before and after the expected date of delivery.
- Extending benefits for complications is possible.

metadata.Header 1: Benefit Calculation

text:
Payment Process
- Benefits are paid on the eighth day of leave after the waiting week.
- Issued on debit cards mailed by Money Network/My Banking Direct.
- Funds are available within three business days of the payment date.

metadata.Header 1: Benefit Calculation

text:
Maximum Benefit Amount
- The maximum amount is capped at one-third of total wages earned in New Jersey or 26 times the weekly benefit amount, whichever is less.

metadata.Header 1: Benefit Calculation

text:
Forms and Mail
- Important forms include Confirmation of Claim Receipt, Eligible Notice, and Ineligible Notice.
- Additional forms like Request to Claimant for Continued Claim Information and New Mother Bonding Notice may be sent based on the application status.
- Requests for medical information are expected if needed for processing.# Information  
You’ll receive this form if your application is missing medical information, if the medical information needs further review, or if your statement conflicts with the medical provider’s statement. For more information about specific forms or notices, see our Form Look Up page.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
Keeping Your Employer Informed  
The Temporary Disability Benefits Law does not specify how far in advance you must notify your employer for medical leave, as many disabilities including complications during pregnancy are unforeseeable circumstances. However, we encourage you to keep your employer informed whether your leave for medical reasons is scheduled in advance or not. Having an open discussion with your employer about your need for leave will allow them to prepare for your absence and make adjustments to work schedules, if necessary. Your employer may also be able to provide insight on job protection and if you qualify for it through the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
How the Program Is Funded  
Both New Jersey workers and employers contribute to the cost of the temporary disability program. Workers contribute through deductions taken out of their paychecks. For 2022, workers contribute 0.14% on the first $151,900 (wage cap) in covered wages earned during this calendar year. The maximum worker contribution for 2022 is $212.66. This contribution is in the form of a salary deduction that your employer takes from your weekly wages. There will be no Temporary Disability worker contribution deductions for the 2023 and 2024 calendar years.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
How to File an Appeal  
If you disagree with our decision, you may submit an appeal. Click [here](link) for more information about the appeals process.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
How to Pay Back An Overpayment  
Did you receive a Demand for Refund (P60) notice in the mail? We try to make the process of repayment as easy as possible. Click [here](link) for more information about the repayment process.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail
metadata.Header 2: How to Pay Back An Overpayment

text:
How Temporary Disability Benefits are Taxed  
Temporary Disability Insurance benefits are considered taxable income for purposes of both the federal income tax and FICA (Social Security). Federal income tax will not be withheld from your benefit payment each week unless you request it when you file, or submit IRS form W-4S to us (for state plan claims) or your employer (for private plan claims). Your share of FICA and medicare is automatically deducted from state plan benefit payments. Garnishments and any refunds owed from a previous disability or family leave claim will also be withheld from your benefit payments. Temporary Disability Insurance benefits are not taxed by the State of New Jersey.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail
metadata.Header 2: How Temporary Disability Benefits are Taxed

text:
Private Disability Insurance During Pregnancy  
The Temporary Disability Benefits law allows employers to provide coverage through an approved private plan instead of the state plan. The plan may be insured by the employer, an insurance company, or a union welfare fund. Private plans must offer at least the same benefit amounts, eligibility requirements, and duration of payments as the state plan. If you are covered under a private plan for your pregnancy disability period, your employer's insurance carrier is responsible for processing and paying benefits on your claim. Click [here](link) for more information on Private Temporary Disability Insurance.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
About the Program  
Family Leave Insurance provides New Jersey workers monetary benefits to bond with a newborn. While most New Jersey workers who take family leave are covered under the state’s Family Leave program, some employers provide Family Leave Insurance through a plan with a private insurance carrier instead. If you are not sure about your coverage, ask your employer.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
Filing for Bonding Leave Benefits After Recovering from Birth  
AFTER RECEIVING STATE TEMPORARY DISABILITY BENEFITS:  
You will receive an FL2 (new mother bonding notice) in the mail once we are notified that you delivered. The FL2 has a unique Claim ID Number on it. When you receive the form, [click here](link) and enter that number when asked. If everything goes smoothly, you should receive benefits on your debit card within two business of completing the FL2 online.
keywords: birth after receiving state temporary disability benefits

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail
metadata.Header 2: Filing for Bonding Leave Benefits After Recovering from Birth
metadata.Header 3: AFTER RECEIVING STATE TEMPORARY DISABILITY BENEFITS:

text:
IF YOU RECEIVED PRIVATE PLAN TEMPORARY DISABILITY BENEFITS, OR NO DISABILITY BENEFITS:  
You will need to submit a new application for Family Leave Insurance benefits for bonding with your baby. [Click here](link) to start that process. If planning ahead, you may start your online application up to 60 days in advance.
keywords: if you received private plan temporary disability benefits

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail
metadata.Header 2: Filing for Bonding Leave Benefits After Recovering from Birth
metadata.Header 3: IF YOU RECEIVED PRIVATE PLAN TEMPORARY DISABILITY BENEFITS, OR NO DISABILITY BENEFITS:

text:
To avoid deletion of your draft application:  
(1) within 14 days of starting the application, provide all information and confirm your claim; then (2) within 14 days after the start of your leave, certify and file your claim. If applying after your leave begins, you have 30 days from your first day of leave to file your application.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail
metadata.Header 2: Filing for Bonding Leave Benefits After Recovering from Birth
metadata.Header 3: To avoid deletion of your draft application:

text:
How to Receive Benefits Quickly  
We would like to process your claim quickly, but can’t do it without your help. Keep these tips in mind to avoid delays and receive your benefits faster:
- Apply online.
- Fill out your application completely and accurately.
- Include your Social Security number on all correspondence.
- Don’t fax us pictures of documents.
- Get ready to receive your payments.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
Continuous or Non-Continuous Leave  
New moms do not need to take their leave all at once. You can claim Family Leave Insurance to bond in one consecutive 12-week period, or on a day-by-day basis to suit your needs. However, the manner in which you choose to claim your leave will determine the duration of leave that you are entitled to.  
- Continuous Leave: You may receive up to 12 weeks of benefits before your child’s first birthday, if the benefits are claimed for one continuous period of unpaid leave.
- Non-Continuous (intermittent) Leave: If you are claiming benefits on an intermittent schedule, whether it be a week, a month, or a day at a time, you may receive up to 56 individual days (8 weeks) of Family Leave benefits before your child’s first birthday.  
If you take your leave in a non-continuous manner, let us know those dates after taking each segment. If you are approved for Family Leave Insurance benefits but do not initially claim your maximum amount of leave when filing, we will mail you a Continued Claim Certification (FL3), which includes a schedule that you must fill out and sign – showing the days you did not work during the period. You will need to submit an updated schedule after each period of leave is completed.

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
Who Qualifies for State Benefits  
New Jersey workers are encouraged to apply. In order to have a valid claim for Family Leave Insurance, you need to have paid into the program through your employment and meet minimum gross earnings requirements. Family Leave Insurance is available to most New Jersey workers.  
Exemptions include:
- federal government employees
- out-of-state employees
- faith-based organizations workers that are not technically employees (such as contractors).

metadata.Header 1: Forms and Mail

text:
How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify  
Your employer is required to report your wages to the state after each calendar quarter. When your claim is under review, we consider the earnings reported for the five completed quarters prior to the week your leave began. The first four quarters of that time frame is called the base year.  
To qualify for Family Leave Insurance in 2023, you must have worked 20 weeks earning at least $260 weekly, or have earned a combined total of $13,000 in those four quarters (the base year). To qualify for Family Leave Insurance in 2024, you must have worked 20 weeks earning at least $283 weekly, or have earned a combined total of $14,200 in those four quarters (the base year).  
The minimum earnings requirement for Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance are the same. If you received Temporary Disability benefits from the state for your pregnancy and postpartum recovery, you automatically meet the minimum earnings requirement for Family Leave benefits.# Family Leave Insurance Facts

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
When You're Sick, Injured, or Post-Surgery  
About the Program
Temporary Disability Insurance provides cash benefits to New Jersey workers who have to stop working due to a physical or mental health condition or other disability unrelated to their work. The healthcare provider certifies how long you need to recover from your medical condition, up to a maximum of 26 weeks. Most employers in New Jersey are required to have Temporary Disability Insurance for their employees, and employees may be covered by the state or a private insurance company.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: When You're Sick, Injured, or Post-Surgery

text:
Who Qualifies for State Benefits
New Jersey workers are encouraged to apply for Temporary Disability Insurance, as long as they meet the minimum gross earnings requirements and have paid into the program through their employment. Exemptions include federal government employees, out-of-state employees, and independent contractors. Employees who believe they are covered but have not had payroll contributions made are encouraged to apply.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: When You're Sick, Injured, or Post-Surgery

text:
How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify
To qualify for Temporary Disability Insurance, workers must have worked 20 weeks earning at least $260 weekly or earned a combined total of $13,000 in the base year for 2023. For 2024, the requirements increase to 20 weeks earning at least $283 weekly or a combined total of $14,200 in the base year. The earnings during the base year determine the amount of weekly benefits a worker may receive.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: When You're Sick, Injured, or Post-Surgery
metadata.Header 3: How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify

text:
How the Program Is Funded
Both workers and employers contribute to the cost of the temporary disability program. Workers contribute through deductions taken out of their paychecks. For 2022, the contribution was 0.14% on the first $151,900 in covered wages earned during the year, with a maximum worker contribution of $212.66. There will be no Temporary Disability worker contribution deductions for 2023 and 2024.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: When You're Sick, Injured, or Post-Surgery

text:
How Benefits Are Calculated
The average weekly wage is calculated by dividing the base year earnings by the number of base weeks. Claimants are paid 85% of their average weekly wage, up to the maximum weekly benefit rate set for the calendar year. In 2023, the maximum weekly benefit rate is $1,025 per week, and in 2024, it is $1,055 per week. Weekly benefits are calculated based on the reported wages from the base year.# Temporary Disability Benefits

- The benefits are taxable in the year of payment issuance, not necessarily when the leave occurred.
- A delay in payment issuance may lead to benefits being reported in the following year.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
The Waiting Week for Temporary Disability, Explained  
- The Temporary Disability Insurance program has a week known as the "waiting week" that is initially unpaid.
- Benefits start on the eighth day of disability.
- The waiting week consists of the first seven days of payment, which is held until the condition of unpaid leave continuing for a total of 22 days or more is met.
- If the disability extends to 22 days or more, the individual will receive retroactive payment for the first 7 days.
- Example Scenario:
1. John's doctor disables him from March 1 through March 14 (14 days unable to work):
- Benefits will be issued from March 8 through March 14 (7 days of payment).
2. John's doctor extends his disability period through March 31:
- John qualifies for the waiting week and will receive benefits for March 15 through March 31, along with a retroactive payment for the waiting week (March 1-March 7).
- The Family Leave program does not have a waiting week.
- When applying for Family Leave Insurance, benefits are issued for the entire claimed leave period.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Family Leave Insurance  
General Information
- Family Leave Insurance provides New Jersey workers cash benefits to bond with a newborn, newly adopted, newly placed foster child, or to provide care for a seriously ill or injured loved one.
- Employers may provide Family Leave Insurance through a plan with a private insurance carrier.
- To determine coverage, workers are advised to ask their employer.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How to Apply for Benefits
- Workers can apply for Family Leave Insurance benefits online, by mail, or by fax.
- Detailed instructions are provided within the application.
- Timelines for filing applications before or after a leave begins are outlined.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How to Receive Benefits Quickly
- Tips to avoid delays and receive benefits faster:
- Apply online and do not submit the same claim by mail or fax.
- Complete the application accurately and completely.
- Provide necessary instructions to a family member's medical provider for family caregiving claims.
- Do not fax pictures of documents.
- Stay informed on receiving benefit payments.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Who Qualifies for State Benefits
- Most New Jersey workers are eligible for Family Leave Insurance.
- Exemptions from coverage include specific categories of employees.
- If uncertain about coverage, workers are encouraged to apply for benefits.
- Recent unemployment should not deter workers from applying.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify
- Earnings reported by employers for the 5 completed quarters prior to the leave beginning are considered.
- Qualifying requirements for earning thresholds are specified.
- Benefits are calculated based on the wages earned during the base year.  
For more information, workers can visit the [Official Website of the Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance](https://www.nj.gov/labor/tdi/fli_guide/index.shtml).# Family Leave Benefits in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 3: How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify

text:
How Benefits Are Calculated
- Your average weekly wage is calculated by dividing your base year earnings by the number of base weeks.
- A "base week" is any week in 2023 where you earn $260 or more, and in 2024, it is $283 or more.
- Claimants are paid 85% of their average weekly wage, up to the maximum weekly benefit rate set for each year.
- In 2023, the maximum weekly benefit rate is $1,025.
- In 2024, the maximum weekly benefit rate is $1,055.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Example Calculation
- Steve's total base year earnings were $18,200, divided by 45 base weeks, gives an average weekly wage of $404.
- Steve's weekly benefit rate would be 85% of $404, which equals $343.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Continuous or Non-Continuous Leave
- You can claim benefits for Family Leave Insurance in one consecutive 12-week period or on a day-by-day basis.
- Continuous Leave allows up to 12 weeks of benefits, while Non-Continuous Leave permits up to 56 individual days (8 weeks) in a 12-month period.
- Inform the authority about the dates of leave taken after each segment.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Keeping Your Employer Informed
- Give 30 days' notice for continuous leave or 15 days' notice for non-continuous leave.
- Open discussions help in preparing your employer for your absence and ensuring job protection eligibility.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How You'll Get Your Money
- Benefits are issued on a debit card sent by Money Network/My Banking Direct.
- For Continuous Leave, payments are usually issued every two weeks.
- For Non-Continuous Leave, each day of benefits paid is one-seventh (1/7) of your weekly benefit rate.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:

- C05 - Confirmation of Claim Receipt
- D10 - Eligible Notice
- D30 - Ineligible Notice
- FL3 - Request to Claimant for Continued Claim Information
- Additional forms may be received for missing or conflicting information.

text:

- Family leave program is funded 100% by worker payroll deductions.
- Workers contribute a certain percentage based on yearly wage cap.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Understanding Maximum Benefit Amounts
- Workers can receive benefits for twelve consecutive weeks or up to eight weeks of intermittent leave in a 12-month period.
- Benefits can be reestablished within 12 months to care for a different family member or after employment with a different employer.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Payment Information
- **Continuous Leave:** Payments are issued every two weeks after the initial payment, with a one-week lag for processing time.
- **Non-Continuous Leave:** Each day of benefits paid is one-seventh of the weekly benefit rate.
- **Availability of Funds:** Funds should be available on your debit card within three business days of the payment date.
- **Tax:** No federal income tax is withheld unless you request a 10% deduction when applying.
- **Duration:** Benefits paid until return to work, exhausting maximum benefit entitlement, or child's first birthday.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Employer Communication
- **Notice Requirement:** 30 days before continuous leave, 15 days before each separate period of leave.
- **Benefits Impact:** Reduced benefit entitlement by 14 days if inadequate notice.
- **Informing Employer:** Encouraged for preparation and discussion on job protection under FMLA or NJFLA.

text:
Benefits Calculation
1. **Average Weekly Wage Calculation:** Based on base year earnings and number of weeks.
2. **Weekly Benefit Rate:** 85% of average weekly wage, up to a maximum set for the year.  
For further details on the Family Leave program and benefits, visit the [official website](https://www.nj.gov/labor/).# Family Leave Program in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Calculation of Benefits
- Quarters 1 through 4 constitute the regular base year for benefit calculation.
- ![Base year earnings](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?Total&space;base&space;year&space;earnings:&space;$18,200) divided by 45 (number of base weeks) provides an average weekly wage of $404.
- Steve's weekly benefit rate is 85% of his average weekly wage, which amounts to $343.
- If Steve takes leave on a day-by-day basis, he will receive 1/7 of his weekly benefit rate for each claimed day.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Payment Information
- Applications are processed in the order received.
- Benefits are delayed if the application is incomplete or contains conflicting information.
- Benefits are issued on a debit card by Money Network/My Banking Direct, arriving in a plain envelope.
- Continuous Leave payments are usually biweekly with a one-week processing lag.
- Funds are available within three business days after payment is posted.
- No federal income tax is withheld unless requested.
- Family Leave benefits continue until returning to work, exhausting the benefit entitlement, or the child's first birthday.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Continuous and Non-Continuous Leave
- **Continuous Leave:** Up to 12 weeks before the child's first birthday.
- **Non-Continuous Leave:** Up to 56 individual days (8 weeks) before the child's first birthday; dates must be reported after each segment.
- Employer notification is required for leave initiation.
- Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) or New Jersey Family Leave Act (NJFLA) may also provide job protection.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Funding
- The program is funded solely by worker payroll deductions.
- Workers contribute a percentage of covered wages, with a maximum amount set annually.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Adoption and Foster Parent Benefits
- Bonding time for adoptive or foster parents is covered within a year after adoption or placement.
- Leave can be taken continuously or non-continuously, similar to family leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Applying for Benefits
- Applications can be made online, by mail, or fax.
- Required information includes personal details, employment history, leave start date, and benefits received post-employment.
- Timelines for application submission are provided based on the start of the leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Expedited Benefit Processing
- Apply online and avoid submitting claims by mail or fax.
- Complete the application accurately and thoroughly.
- Be prepared to receive payments via prepaid debit card.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
About the Program
- New Jersey's Family Leave Insurance offers cash benefits to workers for bonding time with a new adoptive or foster child.
- Some employers may provide Family Leave Insurance through a plan.# Family Leave Benefits in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Who Qualifies for State Benefits
- New Jersey workers are encouraged to apply for Family Leave Insurance.
- To have a valid claim, you must have paid into the program through your employment and meet minimum gross earnings requirements.
- Exemptions include federal government employees, out-of-state employees, faith-based organizations workers, and non-employee workers.
- If your employer is covered for Family Leave Insurance, they are required to set up payroll contributions for you.
- If unsure about coverage, ask your employer.
- Unemployed individuals may still be eligible for benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify
- Employer reports wages to the state after each calendar quarter.
- Qualification based on earnings from the previous four quarters (base year).
- Earning requirements: in 2023 - worked 20 weeks earning at least $260 weekly or a total of $13,000. In 2024 - worked 20 weeks earning at least $283 weekly or a total of $14,200.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How Much I Need to Earn to Qualify

text:
How Benefits Are Calculated  
Calculating Average Weekly Wage
- Divide base year earnings by the number of base weeks.
- A "base week" in 2023 is $260 or more, and in 2024 is $283 or more.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Determining Weekly Benefit Rate
- Claimants are paid 85% of their average weekly wage, up to the maximum weekly benefit rate (2023 - $1,025, 2024 - $1,055).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How You'll Get Your Money
- Benefits are issued on a debit card sent by Money Network/My Banking Direct.
- Payments are usually issued every two weeks for continuous leave.
- For non-continuous leave, each day of benefits paid is one-seventh of the weekly benefit rate.
- No federal income tax withheld unless requested.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
How the Program Is Funded
- Financed by worker payroll deductions, not employer contributions.
- Worker contributions based on a percentage of covered wages earned with a wage cap.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Keeping Your Employer Informed
- Give notice before starting leave.
- Keep employer informed for open communication.
- Employer insights on job protection can be through federal or NJ family leave acts.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
What Forms You'll Receive
- C05 - Confirmation of Claim Receipt.
- D10 - Eligible Notice.
- D30 - Ineligible Notice.
- FL3 - Request to Claimant for Continued Claim Information.
- C10 - Request to Claimant for Information (may receive if application contains missing/conflicting information).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Understanding Maximum Benefit Amounts
- Maximum benefit amount is up to twelve consecutive weeks or eight weeks of intermittent leave in a 12-month period.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:

- Submit an appeal if disagreeing with the decision.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Additional Support and Assistance  
Work NJ
- **UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE**: Cash benefits for jobseekers.
- **EMPLOYMENT & JOB TRAINING**: View job openings, take no-cost credentialed online courses, receive one-to-one support.
- **WORKPLACE RIGHTS**: All NJ workers have protections under the law.
- **Job Protection**
- **FEDERAL FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE ACT (FMLA)**: Job-protected leave for specified family and medical reasons.
- **NEW JERSEY FAMILY LEAVE ACT (NJFLA)**: Job-protected leave to care for a loved one.
- **NEW JERSEY SECURITY AND FINANCIAL EMPOWERMENT ACT (SAFE)**: Job-protected leave to handle matters related to sexual and domestic violence.
- **Long-Term Disability Benefits and Services**
- **SOCIAL SECURITY DISABILITY INSURANCE**: Federal program that provides cash benefits and assistance to people with disabilities.
- **SERVICES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES**: Call 888-285-3036.
keywords: federal family and medical leave act
new jersey security and financial empowerment act

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Family, Food, and Child Care
- **PREGNANT OR HAVE CHILDREN UP TO AGE 5?**
- You may be eligible for assistance, including nutrition and food help.
- Dial 2-1-1 or text your zip code to 898-211 and ask for the Help Me Grow Central Intake Hub in your county.
- **UNIVERSAL HOME VISITING**: No-cost home visits from a specially trained nurse within the first two weeks after your child's birth. Available in Essex, Middlesex, Gloucester, and Cumberland counties.
- **WOMEN INFANTS AND CHILDREN (WIC) NUTRITION PROGRAM AFFORDING GROCERIES**: Call 1-800-687-9512.
keywords: pregnant or have children up to age

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:

- **FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR HEALTH INSURANCE**: 9 in 10 enrolling in health insurance at Get Covered New Jersey qualify for financial help to lower costs. Enroll at GetCovered.NJ.gov.
- **AFFORDING HEALTH CARE COVERAGE**: Call 1-800-701-0710.
- **CHILDREN’S MENTAL HEALTH/ADDICTION TREATMENT AND SUPPORT**: Through the Children’s System of Care, NJ’s public behavioral health system.
- **MENTAL HEALTH & EMOTIONAL SUPPORT**: Call 866-202-HELP or 973-870-0677 for ASL videophone.
- **ADDICTION TREATMENT AND RECOVERY**: Call 844-REACHNJ.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:

- **INTERNET AND TECHNOLOGY**: Affordable Connectivity Program benefits households afford internet services and certain devices.
- **APPLY FOR RENTAL ASSISTANCE**: New Jersey COVID-19 Emergency Rental Assistance Program Phase II (CVERAP-II).
- **ENERGY ASSISTANCE**: Universal Service Fund (USF) helps make energy bills more affordable for low-income customers.
- **EMERGENCY HOUSING ASSISTANCE**: Contact community-based agencies in your county.

text:
About the Program
- NJ Temporary Disability Insurance provides cash benefits to employees in New Jersey.
- Benefits are for those unable to work due to physical or mental health conditions, pregnancy, childbirth recovery, etc.
- Temporary Disability Insurance is a wage replacement program and does not provide job protection.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Covered Employees and Employers
- Employers must participate in State public insurance programs or provide coverage through private plans.
- Local governments are optional participants.
- Employees working significantly outside NJ may not be covered, but should apply to confirm eligibility.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
The Employer's Role
- Employers' responsibilities include posting relevant posters, providing written notices, and reporting quarterly earnings.
- Employers must monitor benefits issuance to employees, report inaccuracies, and report taxable portion on W-2s.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Paid Time Off and Temporary Disability Insurance
- Employers may require employees to take paid time off before Temporary Disability benefits based on NJ Earned Sick Leave law compliance.
- Different scenarios exist for combining PTO with the Earned Sick Leave law.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Special Cases: Unique Medical Situations
- **Substance abuse**:
- If the disability is solely due to illegal substance abuse, the patient may still be eligible for benefits.
- Certification required for patient's current drug-free status and enrollment in a rehabilitation program.
- **Non compos mentis ("not of sound mind")**:
- Patient may be mentally unable to handle their affairs.
- Certification needed for patient's incapacity to manage their own affairs.
- **Self-inflicted injuries**:
- Benefits not provided for willful self-injury, though may be payable if an underlying medical condition is involved.
- **Cosmetic surgery**:
- Reconstructive surgery for underlying disabling conditions may be eligible for benefits.
- Cosmetic surgeries solely for aesthetic purposes will not be covered.
- **Organ donation**:
- Benefits payable only post-surgery, not for pre-admission testing.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers  
Year-End Statements  
- Employers can now download their year-end statement for tax information on employees who collected Temporary Disability benefits in 2023.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
2024 Employee Contribution Rates  
- TDI: No employee contribution deductions for 2024.
- FLI: Employees contribute 0.09% of the first $161,400 in covered wages, with a maximum contribution of $145.26 for 2024.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Temporary Disability Insurance  
- Provides cash benefits to NJ employees unable to work due to various health conditions or disabilities.
- Does not provide job protection but employees may have federal law protections.
- Important for employers to display notices, report earnings, monitor benefits, and report to the Division if issues arise.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Covered Employees and Employers  
- Employers must participate in state public insurance programs or provide private plan coverage meeting NJ requirements.
- Temporary Disability Insurance optional for local governments and generally does not cover employees working significantly outside NJ.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Employer's Role  
- Must display required posters, report quarterly earnings, and report taxable portion of benefits on W-2.
- Employers can help by providing information to employees, utilizing the employer toolkit.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Paid Time Off and Temporary Disability Insurance  
- Employers may require employees to take paid time off before claiming Temporary Disability benefits depending on compliance with NJ Earned Sick Leave law.
- Different scenarios outlined for employers to understand how PTO and benefits interact.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers
metadata.Header 2: Paid Time Off and Temporary Disability Insurance

text:
Providing Information  
- Employees who are unable to work need to provide specific information on their application.
- Employers must oversee and assist employees with completing the application accurately.
- Employers should monitor benefit payments and report any incorrect payments to the Division.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Additional Information Requests  
- Employers may be requested to provide additional information if needed for claim approval.
- Forms E-10 or E-20 may be sent to employers if more information is required.# Temporary Disability and Family Leave Program Information

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Required Information for Claims
- **Submission Deadline:** Complete and return the form promptly
- **Consequences of Failure:** Denial of benefits and monetary penalty
- **Employer Information Requested:**
- Federal employment identification numbers
- Paid time off, vacation, or sick time used
- Intermittent workdays
- Employee’s last date of work
- Confirmation of valid wages

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
W-2 Statements for Temporary Disability Benefits
- Available online for download in January for the previous year
- Only a portion of benefits is federally taxable
- Considered third-party sick pay or other wages
- Employees receiving benefits must report taxable information on their W-2

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers
metadata.Header 3: W-2 Statements for Temporary Disability Benefits

text:
Funding the Program
- Funded by contributions from New Jersey workers and employers
- Employer contribution rate varies from 0.10% to 0.75%
- Contributions based on employee earnings, with taxable wage cap changing annually

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Minimum Gross Earnings Requirements
- Based on reported earnings for 5 completed quarters prior to disability
- **Base Year Qualifications:**
- **2023:** 20 weeks earning at least $260 weekly or $13,000
- **2024:** 20 weeks earning at least $283 weekly or $14,200

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Benefit Calculation
- **Average Weekly Wage:** Base year earnings divided by base weeks
- **Weekly Benefit Rate:** 85% of average weekly wage, up to maximum set for the year
- **Maximum Weekly Benefit Rates:**
- **2023:** $1,025
- **2024:** $1,055
- Example provided for benefit calculation

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Application Process
- Claimants submit medical certification of disability by healthcare provider
- Pregnancy claims covered with defined time frames
- Employees file online and involve approved healthcare provider

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Medical Information Confidentiality
- Only shared with the Division of Temporary Disability Insurance
- Authorization required for disclosure
- Protection of medical records and confidentiality assured

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Appeal Process
- Online appeal filing available

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
NJ Family Leave Insurance
- Provides cash benefits for family caregiving, bonding with children, and domestic violence matters
- Job protection during benefit receipt under state or federal law
- Retaliation protection for employees seeking benefits

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Employer Responsibilities
- Display posters, provide notices, report earnings, monitor benefits
- No requirement to complete employer portion of application
- Must ensure benefits are issued accurately

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Employee Requirements
- Complete first two sections of application, providing relevant details
- Work history and wages based on employee's statement and record
- Support from employer in overseeing process

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance for Employers

text:
Assistance for Employee's Application
- Pay close attention to Notice of Eligible Determinations
- Assist employees as needed and ensure accurate information provided# Important Information about Employee Benefits

- Phone number for customer service center: (609) 292-7060

Program Overview  
Temporary Disability Benefits Law
- Option for employers to establish private plans for temporary disability or family leave insurance
- Approval process by the Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Private Plan Requirements
- Basic provisions and operation requirements for approved private plans
- Eligibility, coverage, costs, and contribution considerations

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Private Plan Approval
- Establishment methods for private plans
- Requirements for insurance companies and self-insurance options# Private Plan Operations in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Private Plan Overview  
Private Plans are managed by the employer or a union welfare fund to administer and pay benefits. Modifying or terminating a private plan requires specific procedures to be followed.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Modifying an Approved Private Plan  
- Changes, such as insurance carriers, employee class coverage, eligibility requirements, or benefits adjustments, must be approved by Private Plan Operations.
- Contact the Private Plan Unit for questions about modifying a private plan.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Terminating an Existing Private Plan  
1. **By the Employer**:
- Request termination in writing to the Private Plan Compliance Section.
- Employer notified in writing of the termination and return to State Plan coverage.  
2. **By the Insurer**:
- Written notification to Private Plan Operations for various termination reasons.
- Workers automatically covered by the state plan after termination.  
3. **By the Workers Covered**:
- Requires a petition signed by at least 10% of the employees.
- Private Plan Operations oversees the termination voting process.  
4. **By the Division**:
- Private Plan may be terminated immediately if just cause is found.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Approved Insurance Companies  
A list of companies licensed for short-term group temporary disability and family leave coverage in NJ is provided, for use in insuring approved Private Plans.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Private Plan Claims and Processing  
Private Plan claim handling is overseen by the Private Plan Operations office. Denials of benefits must be in writing and allow for appeal.  
- Appeals can be presented to the Private Plan Hearing Officer and further to the Superior Court.
- The Claims Review Unit helps resolve discrepancies, handle complaints, and offer assistance.

metadata.Header 1: Program Overview

text:
Resources and Contact Information  
- [Private Plan Claims Manual](#): Detailed guide for benefits under approved Private Plans.
- Contact Information for Private Plan Unit.
- Request an office visit to discuss claims procedures and Private Plan details.  
For more information, visit the Private Plan Operations office or contact them directly.# State of New Jersey

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ  
Debit Card FAQ  
When will I receive my debit card?
- A new Money Network/My Banking Direct debit card will be mailed within 10 days after approval if benefits have not been received within the last six months.
- Benefit payments should be available on the debit card within three business days of a scheduled payment date.
keywords: debit card faq debit card faq

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: When will I receive my debit card?

text:
Will I get a new debit card every time I apply for benefits?
- Most customers will receive a new debit card every time they apply.
- The prepaid debit cards are valid for approximately six months after withdrawing all funds.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Will I get a new debit card every time I apply for benefits?

text:
How long does it take for money to be on my card?
- Funds should be available on the debit card within three business days of the payment date.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: How long does it take for money to be on my card?

text:
How is the debit card sent to me?
- The debit card is sent via regular mail in an unmarked envelope with an Omaha, NE return address.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: How is the debit card sent to me?

text:
What time of day can I make withdrawals or purchases with my card?
- Purchases and withdrawals can be made 24 hours a day.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: What time of day can I make withdrawals or purchases with my card?

text:
What happens if my card is lost, stolen, or damaged?
- Immediately call Money Network/My Banking Direct at 888-292-0059.
- One free replacement per calendar year is available, additional replacements cost $10 per card.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: What happens if my card is lost, stolen, or damaged?

text:
Can I transfer funds to my checking or savings account?
- Funds can be transferred to a checking or savings account through the Money Network mobile app or website.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Can I transfer funds to my checking or savings account?

text:
Can the State of New Jersey track my transactions?
- The State of New Jersey cannot view specific card account numbers or transaction details.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Can the State of New Jersey track my transactions?

text:
Who should I call about my debit card account?
- Contact Money Network/My Banking Direct at 888-292-0059 or access account information online.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Who should I call about my debit card account?

text:
Will I be able to add other funds to my debit card?
- Only the New Jersey Department of Labor and Workforce Development can deposit funds into the debit card account.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Will I be able to add other funds to my debit card?

text:
Is there a daily maximum I can withdraw from my debit card account?
- There is no daily withdrawal or purchase limit.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Is there a daily maximum I can withdraw from my debit card account?

text:
Will I earn interest on the funds in my debit card account?
- The debit card account does not accrue interest.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Will I earn interest on the funds in my debit card account?

text:
What happens if I try to make a purchase with insufficient funds?
- The transaction will be denied, and there is no fee for insufficient funds.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: What happens if I try to make a purchase with insufficient funds?

text:
Can using the debit card build my credit history or hurt my credit rating?
- The debit card account is not tied to credit and does not affect credit rating.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Can using the debit card build my credit history or hurt my credit rating?

text:
Where can I get a complete list of fees?
- A complete schedule of fees is provided with the initial debit card package.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ
metadata.Header 3: Where can I get a complete list of fees?

text:
What if I still have a Bank of America debit card from a prior claim?
- A new Money Network/My Banking Direct debit card will be issued, and the Bank of America card will be deactivated after a certain date.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance Debit Card FAQ

text:
Department of Labor and Workforce Development - Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
How Alternate Base Years are Calculated  
Overview
If your earnings during the regular base year do not meet the required minimum, the Division can review your gross earnings in two alternate base year periods to see if they are enough.

metadata.Header 1: Department of Labor and Workforce Development - Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How Alternate Base Years are Calculated

text:
Qualifying for Benefits
- In 2024, you may qualify for benefits if you worked at least 20 base weeks (weeks during which you earned at least $283), or earned at least $14,200 in any one-year period over the last 18 months.
- You cannot pick and choose the time periods you wish to use to qualify.

metadata.Header 1: Department of Labor and Workforce Development - Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How Alternate Base Years are Calculated

text:
Application Review
- When applying for Temporary Disability or Family Leave Insurance benefits, the Division reviews your earnings over the last 12 to 18 months.
- Two alternate base year periods are considered if your earnings during the regular base year period were insufficient for a valid claim.

metadata.Header 1: Department of Labor and Workforce Development - Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How Alternate Base Years are Calculated

text:
Alternate Base Year 1 (ABY1)
- Consists of the four most recently completed calendar quarters before the week your claim began.
- Breakdown of quarters and corresponding dates:
- January 2024 - March 2024 (Based on employment from January 1, 2023, to December 31, 2023)
- April 2024 - June 2024 (Based on employment from April 1, 2023, to March 31, 2024)
- July 2024 - September 2024 (Based on employment from July 1, 2023, to June 30, 2024)
- October 2024 - December 2024 (Based on employment from October 1, 2023, to September 30, 2024)

metadata.Header 1: Department of Labor and Workforce Development - Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How Alternate Base Years are Calculated

text:
Alternate Base Year 2 (ABY2)
- Consists of the three most recently completed calendar quarters before the week your claim began, along with the weeks and wages in the filing quarter up to your last day of work.
- This alternate base year may contain less than 52 weeks.
- Breakdown of quarters and corresponding dates:
- January 2024 - March 2024 (Based on employment from April 1, 2023, to date of claim)
- April 2024 - June 2024 (Based on employment from July 1, 2023, to date of claim)
- July 2024 - September 2024 (Based on employment from October 1, 2023, to date of claim)
- October 2024 - December 2024 (Based on employment from January 1, 2024, to date of claim)

metadata.Header 1: Department of Labor and Workforce Development - Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: How Alternate Base Years are Calculated

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Appealing a Decision  
How to Appeal
- Read the entire notice carefully and follow the instructions within the allotted time frame.
- To file an appeal online, [click here](link).
- Alternatively, file an appeal by writing to the division. Your written statement must include your name, Social Security number, address, and signature and can be faxed to 609-984-4138 or mailed to:
Division of Temporary Disability Insurance,
PO Box 387,
Trenton, NJ 08625-0387.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Additional Information
- If submitting an appeal after the deadline, provide a reason for the delay.
- The appeals examiner will review the information and determine the next steps.
- Allow time for the appeal to be reviewed.
- If no hearing is needed, a division representative may contact you for additional information.
- If a hearing is necessary, you will receive a notice to register for the administrative telephone hearing.
- Register no later than 3 p.m. on the business day prior to the hearing.
- Prepare all necessary paperwork and information for the hearing.
- Witnesses or an attorney can also participate in the hearing.
- After the hearing, you will receive the appeal tribunal’s decision in the mail, along with additional steps if you are unsatisfied.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Appealing a Demand for Refund
- In case of a Demand for Refund, if you are found owing money, start repayment.
- You can arrange a payment plan with the Division of Benefit Payment Control if repayment causes hardship.
- Comfortable repayment amounts are preferable to no payment at all.

Were You Overpaid Benefits?

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
Family Leave During Unemployment  
Information  
- Need to bond with a new addition to your family or care for a loved one, but you haven't worked recently and/or are collecting Unemployment benefits? You may be eligible for Family Leave During Unemployment (FLDU) benefits, a combination of the Family Leave and Unemployment Insurance programs.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Eligibility  
- Family leave claim is processed under the Family Leave During Unemployment program if the first day of family leave is more than 14 days after the last day of covered New Jersey employment and the individual is not on an approved leave of absence from their employer.
- Benefits under this program can be claimed for bonding with a newborn, newly adopted or newly placed foster child, caring for a loved one with a serious health condition, and handling matters related to domestic or sexual violence.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Qualifications  
- Employers are required to report employees' wages to the state after each completed calendar quarter.
- To qualify, one must have worked 20 weeks earning a specific weekly amount or earned a specified total amount in the four quarters (the base year) preceding the claim.
- An alternate base year calculation method is available for workers who do not qualify with a standard base year.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Claim Process  
- Claim start dates vary based on prior approved claims for Unemployment or Disability During Unemployment benefits or, if not collected previously, start from the Sunday of the week in which the first day of Family Leave During Unemployment benefits is claimed.
- Weekly benefit amount is calculated based on average weekly wage, up to a maximum benefit rate set for the calendar year.
- Dependency benefits may be available for qualifying dependents, payable at a specified rate for each dependent.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Benefit Duration  
- Maximum amount of benefits collectively received from Unemployment, Disability During Unemployment, and Family Leave During Unemployment programs is one and one-half times the maximum benefit amount of the initial Unemployment Insurance or Disability During Unemployment.# Family Leave During Unemployment in New Jersey

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Maximum Benefit Amount
- The maximum benefit amount applies to standard Unemployment benefits only.
- Pandemic-related benefit extensions do not impact the maximum benefit amount.
- If approved for Family Leave During Unemployment, the combined benefits cannot exceed one and a half times the maximum benefit amount of the initial Unemployment claim.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Duration and Claiming Process
- Family Leave During Unemployment can be claimed for up to 12 consecutive weeks in a 12-month period.
- Benefits can also be claimed on an intermittent basis for up to eight weeks in a 12-month period.
- Continuous or Non-Continuous (Intermittent) leave options are available.
- Claiming leaves in a continuous period allows for up to 12 weeks of benefits, while intermittent leaves offer up to 8 weeks.
- Weekly claims must follow a Sunday through Saturday schedule, and partial weeks cannot be claimed.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Funding
- The program is funded solely by worker payroll deductions.
- Employers do not contribute to the program.
- Worker contributions vary yearly, with a percentage deducted from covered wages.
- Excess contributions cannot be credited towards tax returns but may be refunded upon request.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application Process
- Apply by completing the Family Leave application (Form FL1) online, by mail, or fax.
- Filing instructions are included in the application, and careful reading is emphasized.
- Required information includes personal details, work history, and reason for separation from the last employer.
- Applications for Family Leave can be submitted up to 60 days in advance.
- Verification of separation may be required if not previously approved for Unemployment or Disability During Unemployment benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Process Tips and Payment Handling
- Tips are provided for a seamless application process to avoid delays in benefit payments.
- Payments are made via a prepaid debit card, and a replacement is available if needed.
- Expectations after applying include temporary denials for routing and subsequent claim reviews.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Timeline and Forms
- Determination times vary based on existing Unemployment or Disability During Unemployment claims.
- Forms for information updates may be sent post-application.
- Debit cardholders must also notify the bank of any address changes.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Additional Contact and Information
- For inquiries or additional details, contact the Division of Employer Accounts, Worker Refund Unit, at PO Box 910, Trenton NJ 08625-0910 or call 609-633-6400.
- Specific forms may be sent depending on the course of the application process.# Family Leave During Unemployment Benefits

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Contact Information
- [Website](https://mbd.everywherepaycard.com/)
- Toll-Free Number: 888-292-0059

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application Process for Family Leave
- **Questionnaire Packet**:
- If Family Leave start date does not align with an existing claim, additional questions may be required.
- Questions may pertain to reasons for leaving work, business ownership, school, or student status.
- Application for dependency benefits and a form for federal income tax withholding are provided.
- Prompt completion expedites claim review.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Benefit Payment Methods
- **For Those Receiving Unemployment or Disability Benefits**:
- Direct Deposit information carries over from the existing claim to Family Leave.
- If not set up for Direct Deposit, benefits are loaded onto a prior debit card.
- Contact Money Network/My Banking Direct for lost cards.  
- **For Those Not Collecting Unemployment or Disability Benefits**:
- Payments are usually via prepaid debit cards from Money Network/My Banking Direct.
- Cards are sent in plain envelopes, resembling junk mail; check carefully.
- Option to transfer funds to a personal account.
- Weekly payments issued, covering full weeks (Sunday to Saturday).

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Reasons for Benefit Reduction/Denial
- Benefits NOT payable for various scenarios, including periods less than a full week, receiving other benefits, full salary periods, working during leave, disqualification reasons, etc.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Tax Information
- State benefits not taxable; subject to federal income tax.
- Option to request 10% withholding.
- Form 1099-G issued at year-end.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Appeals
- Dispute process available with specific timelines and appeal rights.
- Telephone hearings, representation options.
- Results notified via mail.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Independent Medical Examinations
- A routine examination possibly required for care of a family member.
- Ensures proper benefit payments; confidentiality maintained.
- Important to attend the examination to avoid benefit termination.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Transition to Unemployment after Family Leave
- Process for transitioning includes stopping Unemployment claims, applying for Family Leave.
- Temporary denial during transition process; retroactive payment possibility.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance
metadata.Header 2: Transition to Unemployment after Family Leave

text:
Benefit Rates and Durations
- Hybrid program: eligibility for expanded duration but not increased benefit rate.
- Benefits paid at Unemployment rate.
- Maximum benefit limits explained.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Combine Program Benefits
- Maximum total benefits when transitioning explained.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Claim Duration
- Clarification on maximum duration of combined benefits.  
---  
This information provides details on applying for, receiving, and transitioning between Family Leave During Unemployment benefits, including payment methods, tax implications, appeal processes, and coverage limitations.# Unemployment and Family Leave Insurance

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Maximum Benefit Amount
- Capped at a maximum of 39 benefit weeks.
- Not everyone is entitled to 39 weeks if it is more than one and one-half times your maximum benefit amount.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Calculation
- Maximum Benefit Amount = the number of weeks you worked (up to 26 weeks) during the base year period times your weekly benefit rate.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Application Process
- Quickest way to apply is online.
- Alternatively, a paper application can be printed out and submitted by mail or fax.

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions  
What are my responsibilities?
As an employer, you may assist employees in providing employer-related information now required on Part B of the applications. The responsibilities include closely monitoring all benefits issued to employees and notifying the Division if any discrepancies are noted.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions

text:
Notice of Disability Benefits Charged or Credited
- Upon approval of Temporary Disability benefits, the chargeable employer will receive a "Notice of Disability Benefits Charged or Credited" (form DS-7C).
- Pay close attention to the dates and amounts approved to validate the process.
- Notify the Division immediately if benefits are issued for inaccurate days.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 3: Notice of Disability Benefits Charged or Credited

text:
Can I help my employees complete their application?
Assisting employees in completing their application is encouraged to ensure accurate information is provided.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Can I help my employees complete their application?

text:
Temporary Disability Application
- The application only requires information from the employee and the healthcare provider.
- Assistance in completing the form may help clarify employment-related questions.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Can I help my employees complete their application?

text:
What is the best way to monitor benefits issued to employees?
Review the "Notice of Disability Benefits Charged or Credited" for accuracy and track benefits per employee.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: What is the best way to monitor benefits issued to employees?

text:
Checking Benefits
- As an employer, keep track of benefits issued to employees for validation purposes.
- Maintain a separate file for each employee receiving benefits to monitor charges.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: What is the best way to monitor benefits issued to employees?

text:
How do I report incorrect information on an employee's claim?
If benefits are issued for days that the employee worked, received vacation pay, or sick pay, promptly notify the Division to rectify any inaccuracies.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: How do I report incorrect information on an employee's claim?

text:
Reporting Errors
- Contact the Customer Service Line or fax corrected statements with the employee's Social Security number.
- Ensure accurate benefit payments to employees.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: How do I report incorrect information on an employee's claim?

text:
Why do you need my federal Employer Identification Number (EIN)?
The Employer Identification Number is used to report wages to the State of New Jersey and determine employee eligibility for benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Why do you need my federal Employer Identification Number (EIN)?

text:
EIN Requirement
- Wages under the EIN help assess employee qualifications for benefits.
- Ensure correct reporting of wages for benefit calculations.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Why do you need my federal Employer Identification Number (EIN)?

text:
Do my employees still need to provide me with notice of their leave?
Employees are required to provide notice to their employer for family leave, depending on the nature of the leave and duration.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Do my employees still need to provide me with notice of their leave?

text:
Leave Notice
- Notification requirements for continuous and non-continuous family leave periods.
- Employees must provide reasonable notice for caregiving and bonding leave.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Do my employees still need to provide me with notice of their leave?

text:
Am I being charged for my employee’s Family Leave Insurance benefits?
No, Family Leave Insurance does not have a chargeable employer, and employers are not responsible for any charges related to Family Leave benefits.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance - Employers' Frequently Asked Questions
metadata.Header 2: Am I being charged for my employee’s Family Leave Insurance benefits?

text:
Family Leave Charges
- Employers are not charged for Family Leave Insurance benefits.
- No impact on employer experience ratings for benefits paid to employees.  
---  
*For more information, visit the [State of New Jersey Department of Labor and Workforce Development](https://www.state.nj.us/labor/).*  
{Governor Phil Murphy | Lt. Governor Tahesha Way | NJ Home}

text:
Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance  
When Pregnancy Gets Complicated  
Eligibility for Benefits
- Complications during pregnancy or after delivery may make you eligible for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits beyond the typical timeframe.
- Eligibility requires certification from a healthcare provider stating a pregnancy-related medical problem preventing work.

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Common Complications
- High blood pressure (pre-eclampsia)
- Uncontrolled gestational diabetes
- Incompetent cervix and/or placement of a cerclage
- Symphysis pubis dysfunction

metadata.Header 1: Division of Temporary Disability and Family Leave Insurance

text:
Handling Hazardous Workplace Conditions & Pregnancy
- Danger of hazardous workplace conditions vs. inability to perform regular work duties due to pregnancy differs.
- Pregnant individuals unable to perform duties may qualify for Unemployment Insurance benefits.
- If physically unable to work four weeks before due date, apply for Temporary Disability Insurance benefits.
